city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe, I sub avocado oil (1/3 cup) and honey, molasses or maple syrup for the sugar. Also I will throw in a tbsp or 2 of red river cereal for multigrain, and will throw in half a tbsp of bran for extra Fibre.  Any more than that and you can "tell it's healthy". At our house we're into trickery with healthy things. Avocado oil is available from Costco. It's better for our hair, skin and nails and you can't tell the difference. I take it out of my bread maker to rise in a lightly warmed oven for 20 minutes until more than doubled then leave it in while I turn on the oven to 350. Bake until brown and loaf sounds hollow when you tap it. I get a perfect loaf every time. Also, I use plain, ordinary flour either whole wheat or white, not bread flour and I get perfect bread.

I followed the recipe to a T, so I feel I have the right to review this recipe.  After all, if I had made modifications, then a review wouldn't be appropriate or accurate, right?  ;)

I've been making bread with a bread maker for almost 20 years and this recipe and method is the best basic white bread that has ever come out of my bread maker.  So often, bread from a bread maker is on the heavy side and the bread texture is often times rather heavy.

The bread, using this recipe came out with a delicious flakey crust and a nice and somewhat creamy interior.  It was truly delicious and I don't plan on changing a thing.

Thank you so much, shecooks2.  I have saved this recipe to my recipe cookbook as a permanent fixture.

text:
Made this today. I changed the recipe by some of the others suggestions. I used 2-1/4 tsp. bread machine yeast, 2-1/2 cups bread flour, 1/2 cup whole wheat flour and 1-1/2 tsp. salt. Didn't have vegetable oil, so used olive oil. Other than these changes, I followed the recipe exactly. Before the last rising, I quickly took the paddle out, placed the dough back into the pan & back into the bread maker. The bread came out perfect & no big paddle hole in the bottom. (I have an older bread machine & this was the 1st time I tried taking the paddle out) Next time, I'm going to try baking it in the oven for a change. This is definitely a keeper!

I've made this bread 3 times this week since coming across the recipe for my hubbie, 2 year old, and myself, and we aren't the 'bread with every dinner, sandwich every day for lunch' type of people-it's so good!  I make it exactly as the recipe says, using either olive oil or vegetable oil, although I may try butter next time to see how it turns out.  I have been making bread for a long time, but not so long that I was turned away by the mixing method.  I make the dough in my machine then put it in a 9x5 pan (the Gold ones from Williams-Sonoma are fantastic), let it rise again then bake at 350.  Even the first loaf I made that I forgot to let rise turned out pretty well, just more dense.  Can't go wrong with this recipe.

None
text:
Great recipe. It's our go-to recipe and we've gone through at least 25 lbs flour using it and our bread machine.

I like to weight ingredients, and here are the gram equivalents, in the order we add them to the machine:

1 Cup Water (236G)
1/4 Cup Vegetable Oil (56G)
1 Tsp Salt (4.2G)
2 Tbsp Sugar (16G)
3 Cups Flour (384G All Purpose or 408G Bread)
1/4 Oz Yeast (7g)

Enjoy!

text:
This recipe is amazing!  I love it.  When I first started making it in my bread maker, the loaves were kind of compact, but still good.  I made this bread for several weeks before I made a discovery.  If you use 1 cup of warm milk (110 degrees) instead of water, the bread loaf will be almost twice the size.  I don't use bread machine yeast, just regular yeast.  However, I do use bread flour.  The loaf made with milk was lighter, had an even better flavor and produced far fewer crumbs than the loaf made with water.  My family ate the entire loaf within two hours.  This recipe will definitely be a staple in our house.

While I have no problems with the rise, density and texture of this bread using my Breadman TR2700, I found it to be quite bland when compared to other machine and hand-made breads. I made the recipe exactly as directed, but I believe it needs more salt and possibly a little more sugar to be a five-star recipe. If you like to eat bread without loading it down with spread, you'll want to beef up the flavor; I will probably make this again, but I will definitely modify it.

text:
great recipe!! I followed the advice from previous members and added 1 1/2 teaspoons of quick yeast to the recipe, cooked it in the oven after I used the "dough" cycle on my machine, for 23 minutes at 350F. It was beautiful! I topped it with melted butter, YUM! I will be saving this one.

Just wanted to share the 100% whole wheat version: I used 3 tablespoons of raw honey instead of sugar-- 2 cups of stone ground  whole wheat flour -- One cup of white whole wheat flour --  and 3 tablespoons of vital wheat gluten. That would be 1 tablespoon per 1 cup of whole wheat flour. when I add my wet ingredients and my yeast I allow them to sit for 10 minutes to activate the east. Then I add my one cup of whole wheat flour mix and allowed to sit for 20 minutes. Then add the rest of the ingredients with a little more warm water.  make sure the dough is mixed but not too sticky.  Continue following the recipe stated above. I make three loaves every week and it turns out perfect every time.

userID:
1057790
Display Name:
DEELIGHT
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe.  The recipe tends to over-proof in the bread machine, even with 1 1/2 tsp of salt. Over-proofing results in a loaf that doesn't rise (or may even collapse) during the bake cycle. I add 1 tablespoons of vital wheat gluten (70%) for a more chewy texture.

I get best results using the dough cycle on my machine and baking the loaf in the oven.   After using dough cycle, I gently knead to remove air pockets and shape the loaf (on a floured surface to prevent sticking).  I put the loaf in a greased pan, score the top of the loaf and lightly brush with melted butter (oil is also fine, just doesn't have the same flavour).  I cover the pan, leave it in a warm spot for 25 minutes and then bake at 350 for 35 to 40 minutes.  The loaf will rise considerably in the first 15 minutes of baking.  

If I use the bread machine for the entire process, I stop the second raising cycle 10 minutes early and then use the bake cycle.

city:

country:

text:
With only 2 T sugar and no milk or eggs, this is the perfect recipe for my diabetic granddaughter and vegan in-laws.  My husband's eyes lit up and he said it was the best bread I have ever made! I didn't have bread flour, bread machine yeast, or vegetable oil so I used sifted all-purpose flour, regular yeast, and canola oil.  I set the bread machine to the dough setting.  When done, I divided the dough into 4 equal portions, put each portion into a mini-loaf pan, let rise for about 30 minutes, then baked in a 350 oven for 20-25 minutes.  The second batch (2 batches in 1 day!) i substituted 2T honey for the sugar and whole wheat flour for 1/2 of the white flour.  It was just as good. The third version I used the 2 T homey, 1 2/3 c. sifted all-purpose flour, 1/3 c. quick-cooking oats, and 1 c. whole wheat flour.  Turned out perfect again!  This recipe is definitely a keeper!!!

text:
Wow. So simple and so good.  I have a old Sunbeam 1.5lb breadmachine. Followed the directions, putting the water, sugar and yeast in first.   Used 1 active dry yeast packet which is 1/4oz or 7 grams.  Increased the salt to 1.5 teaspoons, I did use Kosher salt.  Towards the end of the final mixing, when my machine beeped, I added some chopped garlic, basil, oregano and parmasean cheese, all room temperature.  

The result was an amazing loaf of crusty italian bread.  Yummy!

This was fantastic! The only changes I made were brown sugar instead of white, 1 teaspoon of kosher salt (equivalent to 1.25 tsp regular salt) instead of regular salt, and substituted 1 cup of flour with multigrain flour. The bread was moist, not too dense and had a crispy crust. I used the "Sandwich" setting for a 2 lb loaf on my Sunbeam. Thanks so much for the great recipe!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an amazing recipe just as it's written.  I make a loaf every other day. Last night I tried a little experimentation and came up with an excellent variation.  First added 1 Tbs brown sugar and 1 Tbs molasses to the machine.  Then added 2 slightly rounded Tsp of Red Star Active Dry Yeast followed by 1 cup of 110 degree F water.  Let set 10 mins.  Next I added 1/4 cup grapeseed oil, 1 cup of bulk Oat Flour, 1 cup of Bob's Red Mill Unbleached White Flour, 1/2 cup of bulk Whole Wheat Flour, and 1/2 cup of bulk High Gluten Flour, followed by 2 Tsp. of salt.  Set the machine for Basic Dark Crust and got a great loaf of a darker bread for toast, sandwiches, or just sliced with butter and jam.  When I call flour "bulk" above, I mean flour I purchased from a market that sells grains and flours in "bulk".  You just scoop out what you want into a bag and they weigh it at check out.

text:
This is the best recipe for making delish fluffy bread!! The only modifications I make is using 2 tsp salt, adding 1/4 c of honey, 1/4 c flax seeds, and occasionally 1/4 c poppy seeds.. I mix and let the dough rise in the bread machine; however, I bake the bread in the oven (it seems to cook better here as opposed to the bread machine) at 375 degrees for 35 minutes.  It's hard not to take a bite of the top when it is cooling!!

text:
Just tasted my first piece & hubby & I agreed that it was the lightest bread to come out of either of our bread machines - ever!  We've each had a bread machine for 12 or 13 years, so a lot of loaves.  I did follow the recommendation to add 1.5 t salt.  I used AP flour & followed the Joy of Baking's substitution rule of 140 grams AP.  When I cut into this bread, I joked with my husband that we'd made a loaf of Wonder bread.  Much tastier, but that gives you the idea of how light it is.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great bread.  I've made a couple of changes that made this a really good bread.  I've used 2 1/4 tsp. of bulk fast rising bread machine yeast, 2 1/2 cups bread flour and 1/2 cup of wheat flour and 1 1/2  tsp. sea salt.  I like oven baked loafs of bread better than the bread machine loaf.  I did as directed in the bread machine until the first rise and right after the punch I removed from machine and placed the dough in a greased bread pan.  Let rise for approx. 60 min. or until the size you desire.  Bake at 350 for 30 min.  Texture and taste was perfect.   I'll be making the bread this way from now on.  A big hit with my family.

text:
I just got a bread machine and this is one of the first recipes.  It turned out really good!

Changes I made:
I used regular Active Dry yeast 2-1/4 tsp
I I increased the salt to 1-1/4 tsp on the recommendation of a previous poster.

I did everything else exactly as in the instructions.  My bread machine is supposed to be capable of a 2.5 pound loaf.  However this recipe fillled the bread pan to capacity!  The texture is nice.  The crust is flaky and crunchy.  I liked the crust but some people in my family did not.  Just personal preference.

text:
This is my second loaf of bread in my new breadmaker. The first was a recipe from the manual that came out bland, tough and dense. This recipe makes an amazing white bread! I too added an extra 1/2 tsp salt and an extra tbsp of sugar. It rose within a half inch of the top of the breadmaker. The kids love it! Tastes like the homemade white bread I remember eating as a kid.  I am going to try some substitutions such as applesauce in place of oil as one other reviewer did to cut down on calories. I think I will also try using honey instead of sugar too since it is better for you, and probably adding in some ww flour in place of half of the bread flour.  But don't get me wrong, the recipe is awesome as it is. I just try to use healthier substitutions when I can.  Thanks for posting!!

text:
I was very hesitant to try this recipe as I have only had my machine a couple weeks. I have only tried making french bread and the white bread recipe they had in the book. The white bread did not turn out good but my family loves the french bread. This recipe went against everything I was told so I read all the reviews and made some suggested adjustments. I reduced the yeast to 2 tsps. and subsituted 2 tbsps of honey for the sugar. Added just a little extra salt and a tbsp of butter in with the dry ingredients. Also did 2 1/2 cups of bread flour and 1/2 cup of wheat flour. I cooked it on the 1 1/2 lb setting for white with light crust and it came out amazing. easy to slice for sandwich bread and my family is loving it. If you are new to bread making or even if you aren't try this recipe.. it is excellent!!

text:
Wow. This is my fourth attempt at making bread. The first three loaves came from a recipe with the manual and they tasted good, but not great.   But this recipe tastes amazing! I followed another user's suggestion by trying 1/2 cup whole wheat flour, and 2 1/2 cups bread flour. I also only used 2 teaspoons of yeast. I added 4 teaspoons of gluten, which is supposed to make the bread rise and soften.   The bread tasted amazing! I was real nervous about leaving the yeast in the water, too. The inside of the loaf was soft and perfectly cooked throughout, the crust was not as hard as the previous loaves, the quality of the bread was soft and chewy. I love it!

text:
My daughter sent us a bread machine for our February birthdays.  I started with pre-packaged mixes, and while very good, they are also expensive.  I found this recipe while searching for a lighter, less dense bread.  It does go against everything my bread machine manual instructs!  I tried it with the variation of adding 1/2 tsp. more of salt and it came out great.  Then I got a little bolder and tried the variation using 2 cups of white bread flour and 1 cup of wheat flour, and 3 tablespoons of sugar.  I left the salt at 1 tsp. as in the original recipe.  Every time I make it it comes out perfect.  It' the family favorite now!  Thanks!

This recipe is fantastic!  I was nervous about putting the ingredients in the machine in the order given, but I trusted the other reviewers and it turned out great!  I used regular flour and yeast because I didn't have any specifically for bread machines.  It didn't matter.  The top of my first loaf fell, so I took another reviewers advise and increased the salt to 1 1/2 tsp.  My second loaf didn't fall and was beautiful.  We were so broke this week I couldn't even afford to go buy a loaf at the store and still had three days of lunches to make for my husband.  I pulled out my machine, dusted it off and gave this a try.  What a life saver!  Thanks Diggetydog and to all the people who took the time to review!

text:
I didn't think this recipe would turn out properly because, as with other reviews, my machine directs to NOT allow the yeast to touch the liquid...the exact opposite of this recipe. I was never really satisfied with the texture of the bread from my machine. It was always heavy and dense. I decided to give this unconventional recipe a try and I was so glad I did! It is AMAZING! The texture is perfect....better than any homemade bread I'd ever produced. I did increase the salt to 1.5 tsp and increased the sugar to 3 Tbls on the advice of other reviewers. Hands down, the best basic bread recipe ever! Thank you for submitting this recipe! I've learned my lesson: always give the unexpected a try!

Used this recipe last night to make Dinner Rolls.  I added everything to Bread Machine as listed, however I did add a little extra salt as 1 reviewer recommended.  I was in a hurry, so did not let the yeast and water sit for the 10 minutes called for.  This bread rose very nicely on the dough cycle. Will use this recipe again and again.

Unbelievable! I am both astounded and thrilled to death! My first loaf of bread from this recipe came out of my machine about half an hour ago...and I LOVE it!! I had a bread machine years ago, and gave it away because no one wanted to eat the heavy, tough and dense bread that came out of it. I recently bought another machine because the closest grocery store is 45 minutes away AND I had found this recipe and it gave me hope that not all bread machine bread is tough and chewy. This recipe tastes NOTHING like others I have tried. I am sooo excited!! I was concerned about the over-rising of the bread, so I did add 1/2 tsp. salt to keep that from happening. I love the smell, the flavor, the crisp crust, the wonderful soft insides. It's not the least bit tough!! I am soooo excited! Thank You!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making all of my family's bread using this recipe for about a year now with fool-proof, fantastic results. I recently switched from whole wheat to whole GRAIN flour and for the first time, this recipe failed me. My bread would rise to a point, then it would seem to struggle under the weight or structure of the flour. I reached out to other allrecipe memebers for help via the buzz and Marie C. suggested I try VITAL WHEAT GLUTEN. The package said to add 1 TBSP of vital wheat gluten per cup of flour, so I reduced my flour by 3 TBSP and added the vital wheat gluten in it's place and... I GOT MY RISE BACK! All you have to do is check out my profile picture to see the difference it made. Thanks SHECOOKS for the awesome recipe, and thanks Marie C. and those fellow cooks who offer advice and help on the buzz for helping  me get my rise back :)

text:
Great basic bread recipe! Proofing the yeast first was an unusual, welcome change. I've tried packaged bread-machine breads & other recipes that do NOT stand up to this one's ease & consistent results. The short ingredient list is a definite plus!  If white bread is too bland for you, I've modified it at times to change the taste (like adding sesame seeds, toasted pumpkins seeds, cinnamon, using wheat flour, etc.) & the recipe stands up to these additions. My bread machine makes a thick crust, too, so thanks for the tip on how to soften it (put bread in a plastic bag directly after baking so that it's own steam will soften the crust). Thank you for sharing this recipe...This has become a staple at my house!

text:
I have owned my machine since 2003 and have used it alot. Never have I made such a wonderful light and fluffy bread. I love my machine but was tired of bread that wasn't soft like the store bought. So I tried this recipe and like many was a bit leary on the mixing yeast with the water. My machine says not too. But I listened to my trusty family on line here and WOW this was truly amazing. 
I follwed the suggestions of eveyone and added an extra 1/2 tsp salt.
I used some Whole wheat flour as well.
I set the machine and took off. When my family come home there was a beautiful loaf of perfect bread waiting for us to chow on. Only one problem.....we ate it all too fast and now it's gone...have to make more.
I love that there are only 6 ingredients!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I recently bought my Oster bread machine in the U.S.  I carefully followed the white bread recipe to the letter, it was heavy and looked overbaked.  I tried it a second time with the same results.  So then I turned to All Recipes and found this recipe.  It turned out just wonderful.  I added the extra salt and instead of baking it for one hour at the end of the kneading processes, I baked it for 40 minutes.  Perfect loaf and just delicious.  For those of you who follow the machine instructions and are not happy, try reducing the bake time.  Also worth a mention is that the bread flour in the U.S. seems heavier than that in Canada, thus the Canadian flour makes a lighter loaf.  Thank you to the person who submitted this recipe and to All Recipes for putting it online for all of us!

text:
I did 2.5 tsp of yeast and 1.5 tsp of salt as recommended. I have made it several times and it is consistently a great bread.  One note...I have 'bread machine yeast' and it says to let it come to room temperature before using.  I didn't wait for it to come to room temperature the second time I was making this bread, and it turned out much drier - not light and moist like it did every other time.

text:
I just bought a brand new bread machine at a rummage sale that did not come with intructions. So I decided to try this recipe for my test loaf.

  I have to admit, I was about 3 tablespoons short for my 3 cups of flour. Since my 2 year old was sleeping, and I didn't want to wake him to run to town for more flour, I added some powdered milk to make up for the difference.

 The taste was still excellent. The loaf did fall a bit but that was probably do to my hap-hazzard substition and the fact that I just guessed on what setting to put the bread machine on since I didn't have the manual..

 It did come out very flaky and delicious. My husband tore into it. 

 I will use this again, (next time with the proper amount of flour). I could only be better when I do it the proper way.

text:
It's official...I'm a convert. I've been struggling with pitiful attempt after pitiful attempt at breadmaking and just recently purchased a bread machine. My first attempt was this recipe and let me say, never again will I knead a lump of dough. I'm sure there are many who will cringe at this admission and - I'm sorry! This was just amazingly easy, so quick and still the end result was a wonderful smell wafting through my home and fluffy, delicious (not to mention edible!) bread. 
A very forgiving recipe this one. I had only all-purpose flour and quick rise yeast on hand so that is what I used. Also, in place of veggie oil I used olive oil. In spite of all these liberties, this loaf still came out beautifully. YUM!

text:
I bake 1-2 loaves of bread a day for my family.  We don't buy premade bread, so I was looking for a new recipe.  I have tried this recipe now four different times in two different bread machines.  I have tried two different bread flours and I have come up with same results every time.  The bread will raise up and then sink and be knotty on top.  The taste of the bread is good enough and it's easy enough to put together, but I have yet to get a nice loaf.  Today, I tried reducing the sugar to 1 tbsp + 1 tsp instead of the 2 tablespoons called for and it was still knotty on top, but didn't collapse quite as bad.  Next time I will try even less sugar.  I think that it's a decent recipe, but something isn't right.  I'll experiment :-)

Finally a great white bread recipe that works in my bread machine!  I've made this twice in the past week and it has turned out perfect!  Easy to make, wonderful aroma as it bakes and almost as good as my Grandma's homemade bread used to taste (with a faction of the work time!).  I used yeast that I knew was fresh and bread flour as indicated in the recipe - the quality of these two ingredients and proofing the yeast are what I believe make this recipe a success.  If it doesn't turn out for you, make sure you have "good, fresh" yeast!.  Will pass this along to family members and this will now be my "Regular" bread machine white bread recipe!!!!*****

I didn't have any bread machine flour or bread machine yeast.  I substituted these items with Gold Metal flour and used 1 package of Fleishman's Yeast.  I also used 1/2 t. salt instead of the full teaspoon of salt in the recipe.  The bread sank a little on one end, but not quite as bad as I have experienced with other favorite bread machine recipes.  The inside was very light, flaky and soft.  The exterior was crusty golden brown.  My husband thought this was very good bread.  Thanks!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fluffy inside, flaky and crisp outside.  I had to use olive oil instead of vegetable oil, but the bread still turned out well.  To avoid collapse in this and any other bread machine recipe, make sure that you're not using too much liquid (water, milk, etc.)--I've found that collapse occurs when the dough isn't thick enough.  Good luck, and enjoy!

text:
I just discovered this recipe yesterday, and am now making my 3rd loaf. It tastes INCREDIBLE. I, like others, have issues with it collapsing, but it still tastes great. When my husband got home last night, he started devouring the loaf I had done. I now am on a mission to figure out how to get it to stop collapsing (I'll report back once I figure out where the problem lies). My machine is a Welbilt ABM4900. In any case, the bread is wonderful, it's so easy to make I've already memorized the recipe, and I may stop buying bread, and just invest in the flour etc. so I can make a fresh loaf of this every day (I can even get it ready the night before when I get the coffee machine, etc. prepped for morning use and set the timer so it's done for breakfast).

*update* I made a loaf yesterday with bread flour instead of all-purpose flour, and it came out PERFECT! Hit the top of the machine. My husband used a slice for his hot dog, loved it. I used it for french toast this morning, and it was fantastic! Now we'll be having this fresh daily - no more store-bought bread here!

text:
Excellent! I was beginning to give up on finding a good basic white bread recipe. I tried the recipe that came with my machine and it flopped. It was dense and sticky and had a sweet flavor to it. I was worried about adding the ingredients against the directions that came with my machine (water first, then flour and yeast on top), but don't doubt it! It works! The only thing I changed was using olive oil because it's what I had on hand. This bread was light and airy with a perfecly crisp crust. I don't know if it will work with the rapid setting I have on my machine, but I'm going to give that a try next using the rapid rise yeast. This recipe is definitely a keeper in my book. Thanks!

text:
Turned out perfectly, I was *very* surprised to see that it came out so very light, fluffy and moist, as if I had baked it by hand.  I used bread flour and bread machine yeast as well as the extra 1/2 tsp of salt as suggested, and used the bread machine method of adding the yeast last into a little well on top of the flour (2.25 tsp).  I baked it in a Black and Decker 3 in 1, and put the machine on 2lb loaf, white bread setting and light crust. As I said, it turned out absolutely perfectly.  This will be my perfect go-to for a wonderful basic white bread.

city:

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe twice now.  The second time, I made a mistake and added Canola oil instead of vegetable oil!  That one bad review said not to use canola and I just did.  When the second loaf finally cooled and I got to taste it, I was shocked to find it tasted........exactly like the first loaf.  I take that back, it actually tasted a little better according to my family.  

So, don't take the advice of the reviewer who cryptically writes " Don't use canola oil, you have been warned." without any other information provided.   Use canola or vegetable and you'll enjoy the bread just the same.

country:
None
text:
This is the best and most versatile bread machine recipe you will ever find. It has tons of  excellent reviews. A few bakers had an issue with cratering. Several causes & solutions were given. Another cause of cratering may be humidity! I made a beautiful loaf in the morning and another loaf which cratered in the afternoon. The only difference was the morning was clear & during the afternoon it was pouring down rain! Apparently, a high humidity causes yeast to rise higher than in a low humidity environment. You must try the cinnamon raisin variation given previously by aliciaVR6 dated Dec 4 2007! It is positively delicious. Only change is I soaked the raisins in hot water for 10 minutes to soften & plump them.

text:
This is an exceptional recipe! I made it countless times with consistent fab results! It actually replaced all my other bread machine recipes! I even made it with fresh yeast (I prefer it when it comes to bread making), whole wheat, every single time it turned out soft, airy and delicious! It slices to perfection, the kids throw slices in the toaster all the time, it doesn't crumble like other breads I've made. Sometimes a loaf would last three days before it gets devoured, and even after three days it is still soft and fresh, with a great texture. I never had bread left over longer than 3 days, but I think it would easily last 4-5 days if stored in a plastic bag. Thank you for this amazing recipe!

text:
totally not an experienced bread machine user. i have only used mine twice. both with this recipe. the first time i tried with the extra salt like other ppl suggested. it was good, but my second loaf done -exactly- as the recipe was posted was much better. also, i used canola oil. i'm not sure why someone said not to use it, because they didn't say why. both loaves were made with canola oil and came out great. when i googled it to see why you shouldn't use it, everything i found said canola oil works perfectly fine in place of vegetable oil because it IS a vegetable oil (i prefer to use it because i'm allergic to soy and most vegetable oils use soy in them). the only thing i could find against it is that if you aren't used to canola, it can possibly have a fishy taste. so if you use canola oil in everything and are used to the taste, you should be fine using canola

text:
This recipe is not only super easy but absolutely delicious!
Have made it several times and each time it was perfection. The only change I made to the original recipe was to increase the salt to 1 1/2 tsp. and add 2 tsp. vital wheat gluten. The amount of ingredients are way too much for my Kitchen  Aid bread machine so I generally make the full recipe, divide the dough in half before the final rise and bake in 2 Cuisine Pro loaf pans. Tried substituting 1/2 whole wheat flour this time and it's our new favorite. Instead of 2 Tbs. white sugar, I used 1 Tbs. white and 1 honey, then added an additional 2 Tbs. honey with the dry ingredients. I also increased the vital wheat gluten to 2 Tbs. My husband is not a great whole wheat fan but even he enjoyed this. If I were making it for just myself, I'd probably use 2 C. whole wheat and 1 C. bread flour but regardless, it's a winner any way you make it. Can't wait to try a rye version. Thanks to the person who shared the original recipe!

9245044
Display Name:
ktvedt

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Will not disappoint. "Kid-friendly".  Great flavor and texture!  TIP:  Some of you are expressing concern over the loaf falling - try adding a tiny bit more salt.  The better answer to fixing this issue is to understand this:  The best way to BAKE ANYTHING is to measure by weight using the metric system.  We Americans differ from almost every other country in the world (except Liberia and Myanmar) in that we use the US Customary measurement system (based off the now defunct Imperial system).  The Metric System measures by weight which accounts for DENSITY.  Here is why that is important - for example:  1/8 cup of kosher salt is very different than 1/8 cup of fine sea salt.  That amount of kosher weighs 1.1 ounces, while the sea salt weighs 1.4 ounces.  The grain is different, the weight is different, the DENSITY is different,  and this affects all the other ingredients.  In baking, US Customary recipes fail far more often than metric.   The fix is to whip out your kitchen scale and start weighing your ingredients.  You will greatly increase your success rate.  Good luck.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-01-12T15:51:38.39
helpfulCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure why some bakers find it odd that the warm water, sugar and yeast are put in the bread pan first for 10 minutes.  It's called proofing.  But the ‘hue and cry’ may be because the instructions for using bread machine yeast recommend that it be added last on top of the dry ingredients.  I believe  that the only purpose of bread machine yeast is for convenience.  I, personally, have never used it for any bread machine recipe.  I don’t mind the extra few minutes to let the traditional yeast proof - at least I know it’s alive.  When the yeast is foamy - about 10 mins - I add any other wet ingredients (e.g. oil), then the dry ingredients and process on the dough cycle.  I bake the bread in the oven (not in the bread machine).  That is how I made this recipe and I LIKE the outcome.

text:
Just a small note, in culinary school anytime I ever made bread of any kind i always started with yeast and water, esp. With active dry yeast it must be activated. The "foaminess" is the yeast releasing gasses, the same gasses which make bread rise. I'm not sure if the same principal generally applies to bread machines.

text:
I made it, and it was pretty good, and got me started but it got a lot better for us with the following changes: instead of 3 cups flour, use 1 cup sourdough starter, 2 + 2/3 cup flour, also added 2 + 2/3 tsp vital wheat gluten, increased to 2 tsp salt decreased to 220 mL water.  I use the french bread cycle on my charlescraft machine.  When I want to use the timer function on the bread maker I put room temperature sourdough starter on top of warm yeast/water/sugar mixture, then flour then vital wheat gluten and salt then substitute unsalted butter for oil putting the butter right at the top

Display Name:
Mrdthbtlr

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my memorized go-to recipe. Makes the lightest bread with crunchy crust. The best. Some tips on my best loaf from this recipe: 
-More salt. I use a heaping teaspoon of good sea salt. It needs it for flavor and I've never had a loaf rise and fall.
-Do not use "bread flour." It's too glutinous and makes for a much more dense loaf. 
-Sub just a 1/2 cup white flour for white whole wheat. Gives depth and nuttier flavor without changing light texture.
-Add 3/4c cooked & cooled wheat berries. (Make sure you cook them until fully soft before adding- too chewy and they will re-harden while baking). They are sweet and chewy and add such a great texture component. 
-Do not use crappy vegetable oil. Yuck!  Using melted Ghee is THE BEST I think- Especially if you use your bread for toast or re-warm it. But I also love using nut oils- walnut, pecan or almond oils if I'm going to use the loaf for eating at room temp- like sandwich bread. The oils make for a softer interior at room temp.

text:
Me and the kid made this today.  I followed a review on here's suggestion of using 2tsp yeast and 3Tbs sugar.  The first time I tried to make it the yeast didn't really foam up so I dumped it out, cleaned out the pan and dug out my food thermometer.  Once I made sure I was using 110F water, it looked much better.  Question if anyone reads this, are you supposed to stir the water, yeast, sugar mixture?  I gave it a quick stir before it started activating but I wondered what was recommended.  Bread is good, kid loves it.  Crust is a bit hard but I didn't know if I should put the machine to 1.5lb or 2lb so I put it at 2 with medium darkness of crust and it was a bit thick and dark...but more than likely that was a user error.  I will definitely make this again and try it with the bread machine set to 1.5lb and with a lighter crust.  We're still eating it with butter and jelly though!

text:
I was nervous about trying this bread.  Most of the reviews are glowing, but the bad ones are pretty bad.  I read ICYBLUEROSE's advice of increasing the salt to 1.5 tsp to avoid the bread rising and falling.  Decided to give it a shot.  Maybe 5 minutes into the cycle I drizzled in a small amount of water, to help the dough come together.  The bread did rise to the lid of the machine, but did not spill over.  That's the only negative.  The bread tastes good and has a nice texture.  My husband loves white bread, and is really happy with it.  The next time I bake this bread, I will try closer to 1.25 tsp salt, to see if that will prevent it from touching the lid. ~~~Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made my own version based off of this recipe and other suggestions from reviewers. I used 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt, 3 tablespoons of sugar, 1 cup and 1 tablespoon of water, 2 teaspoons of rapid rise yeast, 1/4 cup melted butter, 2 1/2 cups bread flour and 1/2 cup whole wheat flour. I selected 1.5 for loaf size and medium for crust. This is my first ever loaf I've made and it is dense in the bottom and more airy in top. Any suggestions for it to be more dense throughout, rather than airy on the top part of the loaf?

This was the first time I've used my breadman bread machine in years. I had tried using it a couple times years ago but it wasn't very good so it went to the back of the cupboard. I'm thrilled to have found this recipe and tried it! I only had canola oil so I used that and I did use 1 1/2 tsp of salt after reading the comments. I am interested in eating healthier and when I found out some of the things they put in bread at the stores I was determined to make my own. I'm going to start experimenting with this recipe, use some other flours, sweeteners and get some quinoa in there. Thanks again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made for the first time today using an Oster bread machine.  The bread came out as advertised.  There was one minor problem.  The bread machine has three settings for doneness LIght, Medium and Dark.  Not knowing how this recipe would respond to these settings I selected medium.  When time was up the loaf was nearly white.  Since the bread machine did not allow the time cycle to be over ridden i.e. adding another 10 minutes to the baking cycle, I took the loaf pan out of the machine and placed it in my regular oven at 350 degrees for 10 minutes.  It came out a perfect brown color just as bread should be.

Other then that making bread in a machine is a simple as it can be.  Having made bread the old fashion way the machine takes all the work and time out of making home made bread.

The only down side of a bread machine is the paddle getting stuck in the bottom of the loaf.  Next time I do this recipe will place the machine on DOUGH ONLY setting.  Then will transfer the dough into a regular loaf pan for baking.  That will make a traditionally looking loaf.

The bread tastes great!  Nice brown crust with a wonderful light, soft texture inside.

BTW, did not use canola since one comment cautioned against it. Use safflower oil instead.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I saved this recipe before my bread maker died but I wanted to try it anyway. I didn't change any of the ingredients. I used canola oil. The method had to change of course. For those without a bread maker - this is how it can be done. Whisk the water, yeast and 1/2 cup flour together. Let sit for 10 mins. Add all other ingredients and in a Kitchen Aide, fitted with a bread hook ,  knead for 10 mins scraping the side of the bowl if needed. Wipe out bowl and drizzle with olive oil, place dough in bowl and turn to coat and let rise for about 1 hour. After it has risen form loaf and let rise again. Brush with well beaten egg and a little water. Bake. This was so moist and tasty. Thanks Shecooks2, this will go into our regular rotation.

text:
I used a sort of amalgam of all of the different alterations I found in the comments here and the loaf turned out fantastic! Until now I've only ever used the recipes that came with my bread machine but the loaves were always really heavy and dense, and the top always caved in. Based on the reviews, this recipe seemed like the perfect antidote to my bread machine slump. I specifically wanted to use it for sandwiches so I used a bit of whole wheat flour to give it substance, 2 1/2 C of bread flour and 1/2 C whole wheat. I also added a heaping tablespoon of honey along with the sugar and, like most here, that extra 1/2 tsp of salt. The result was soft and light, slightly wheaty (not a word, I know), very mildly sweet, and held up PERFECTLY for my turkey sandwiches! My roommate raved about the bread all afternoon! I'm so glad to have this recipe and can't wait to share it with my family and friends!

country:

text:
I Could not make a good loaf of bread using the bread maker instruction. So I put it way forever until I came across this new method of bread making.
It only turned out good once or twice in the past.

I used regular flower and went by the instructions using a packet of yeast, my machine is rated for a 1 1\2 loaf size. The bread ball when rotating was very dry and didn't look good, so I kept adding water or a little milk until it improved and stuck to the sides of the bread maker slightly in a soft ball. I kept an eye on this ,opening the lid occasionally to make sure it looked good until it went to the bake cycle. I looked through the top and watched the bread eventually rise and was just touching the top lid. Afraid the lid would open slightly with the force of the loaf , I put weight on the top of the bread maker. I figured if the lid opened even slightly the loaf might co laps. I saw the loaf stopped rising to the top when , it went to the bake cycle. It worked the top of the loaf did drop a inch or two in the end, but it turned out perfectly. I was really happy, will try the little extra salt next time , may not have to weigh down the top.
Wonder if this is why others are having problems with collapsing , maybe the loaf hits the top and cool air makes this happen?
Just a easy recipe to follow! I think it's time for a slice of bread.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, but I made a couple changes of my own. Instead of 3 cups bread flour, I use about 1 cup whole wheat flour and 2 cups bread flour. While the machine is still mixing the other ingredients, I add about 4 Tbs of cinnamon and about 6 Tbs of honey. Local is best is you can find it. If not, I like Clover honey. Since honey is thick, sticky and hard to work with fast, I get that measured and poured into a small wide mouth jar or bowl ahead of time. It turns out great, and the addition of the wheat flour, cinnamon and the honey, gives it a little more healthy kick to it. Naturally those additions make it a sweeter bread, but I've not found it to be unsuitable with any dish I've made so far. Give it a try! Just beware that the delicious smell while it cooks may drive you crazy. lol

country:

text:
I don't review recipes on here often, mostly because I end up "tweaking" the recipe.  With this bread however, I did absolutely nothing to it AND IT IS AMAZING.  I have this bread going all the time now, whether it is in my machine, rising or baking (sometimes all 3 at the same time), my dh and 17 yo son eat this CONSTANTLY!!!
I have also found it to be a VERY forgiving recipe, for those days I am super busy and add too much water, or let it rise for 2 hours instead of 1.  I have found that I prefer the bread with 1/4 of melted BUTTER instead of oil.  I also just make the dough in my machine, then pat it into my loaf pans and let it rise til doubled and bake at 350 for about 10 mins.  Another quirk of mine (from my Gramma), is that I always put a pan of water in the oven when I bake bread.  I also brush the tops of the bread with melted margarine OR butter right before I pop them in the oven.
Seriously, give this recipe a try, you will not be disappointed!
BIG THANK YOU TO SHECOOKS2!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Display Name:
ReneeP

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to basic bread recipe.  I have make this recipe or a variation thereof 2-4 times a month for 3 years.  Two things I always do with it are temp the water and proof the yeast.  There's nothing worse than waiting 3 hours for delicious fresh bread, only to find that it didn't come out right!  Those two steps prevent that from happening.  Other than that, I frequently do substitutions and variations.  This recipe works fine with all-purpose flour.  I've also substituted a cup of whole wheat flour for one cup that the recipe calls for and had it come out great.  Other substitutions:  brown sugar or honey for the white sugar, olive oil, soft butter or margarine (one time, I even used bacon grease) for the veg oil.  You can also add herbs and/or cheese to this recipe.  If you add cheese, though, it's best to take out a little bit of the water due to the moisture in the cheese.  Too much moisture can make the top of the loaf fall.  Overall, this is just a great recipe, both on its own or as a jumping off point for creative variations.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I have been using this recipe 4 times a week for over a year now.  Amazing results and I am never dissappointed.  Throw out the recipe that came with your bread maker!  I make this on a dough setting, quickly knead the dough in my hands, throw into greased pan, let rise for about 40 minutes in slightly warmish oven,then bake at 350 for half hour or so.  The possibilities are endless for cheese bread, raisin bread, etc.  At first it seemed too easy and I was reluctant, but I am glad I tried it.  By baking it in the oven the house smells divine and you choose your crust color.  Thank you for a great recipe!

Happy

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is slightly too large for the Zojirushi mini. It hit the top of the lid so the crust was not browned or completely cooked there but other than that, it was fantastic. So if you have a mini you'll either need to adjust the ingredients or pop it into a bread pan for the second rising then finish in the oven. I may play around with both options.

I also made the following adjustments per other reviewers' suggestions.  I used 2 generous tablespoons of honey instead of sugar and 2 tsp. active dry yeast (regular) and a slightly heaping tsp. of salt.  After the yeast softened and before adding the flour I added about 1 T. of firm butter to the liquids, and 1/4 cup organic high oleic sunflower oil. Then I added 2 cups of bread flour, 1 cup sprouted wheat flour, 1 T. powdered milk, and the salt.

Delicious. Soft on the inside and perfect flaky crust with a lovely and tasty texture/flavor like nothing I've ever had from a bread machine before. The recipe seems fairly forgiving making it amenable to alterations and substitutions. Way better than the recipes that came with my machine. Not even in the same league.

text:
This recipe was successful for me the first time out. It made a nice sandwich bread. I followed a reviewer's suggestion and reduced the yeast to 2 teaspoons and increased the salt to 1 1/2 teaspoons, which worked perfectly. My bread machine, like others, says not to let the yeast touch the water, but I followed the directions here - letting the yeast dissolve and foam for 10 minutes in the warm water before adding the other ingredients - and it worked! 

I'm making it again tonight. Thanks for the great recipe! (And it's so much simpler than the bread recipes that came in the bread machine manual.)

country:
None
text:
This is hands down the best bread machine recipe I've tried. I've tried quite a variety, and this takes the cake.

After a bit of trial and error, I've made the following changes:
- You do not need to dissolve the yeast for ten minutes if you are using bread machine yeast
- I've adjusted the salt to 1 1/2 teaspoons
- Instead of three cups of bread flour, I use 1 1/2 cups of both white and whole wheat flour (just to make it a bit healthier).

Before I made these small modifications, it was still the best bread recipe I've used, just a little inconsistent. Now, it's amazing bread every time. Thank you!

I had good success with this recipe, adjusting for a 2 pound loaf and adding a bit more salt (2 tsp total). text:
Pulled out my bread machine for the first time in over 5 years. Couldn't find my manual so looked for a recipe. My husband doesn't like wheat bread so I found this easy-looking white bread recipe. I did follow suggestions from one reviewer, increased sugar slightly to 2.5 T and decreased yeast from 2 1/4 to 2 tsp, and substitute 1/2 cup of wheat flour for 1/2 cup of the white flour called for. It was simple to make and delicious! Not too heavy, but also not all airy and squishy. both my picky daughter and my wheat-hating husband loved it! Will be making more of this. May try adding some honey next time.

This recipe was my first successful bread recipe! However, my husband pointed out that he would have preferred the loaf to be a bit more sweeter so I decided to try it again with double the amount of sugar (the extra 2Tbsp was added later along with the dry ingredients). I also included milk by switching to warm water(3/4 cup) and liquid milk 1/4 cup(lactose-free)mixture. My first bread went flat at the top toward the end of the bake cycle, so I added an extra 1/2 tsp as suggested by icybluerose user. Bread came out great!

I am new to bread making with a machine. My first two attempts had the bread fall. I read that increasing the flour by 1/2 cup would work, and that works great for me. I softened the crust after baking by rubbing with top with margarine and sliced the loaf evenly with my electric knife. This bread is excellent for making toast.

text:
This bread is excellent. BUT, it did take me a few times to get it right. One of the things not mentioned by other reviews is that if you are using yeast that has been refrigerated, you must let it come to room temperature before adding to other ingredients. I also had to add an additional 1/2 tsp salt. I still may try to tweak it to get it just right, as I am still not getting the proper rise. This may be because I am baking at altitude. But the flavor and the lightness of the bread is fantastic.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  I have made it about 8 times in the last couple of weeks with just a few tweaks.  I definitely think it needs at least 1.5 tsp salt, and I ended up adding a little milk the last few times as it seemed quite dry despite using proper measuring procedure.  Also, I have tried making it with all purpose flour and bread flour.  While it will work with all purpose flour, bread flour makes MUCH better bread.  If you do have to use all purpose flour, be sure to get the bread out of the machine soon after it's done, or you will end up with flattened bread.  If this happens, don't throw it away...just toast the soggy bottom slices before serving and it will still be pretty good.  For a twist, I also sprinkled a little instant coffee in the liquids before starting the machine for a bit of color and a slightly smokey flavor.

country:
None
text:
I was hunting around for good bread machine recipes since I wanted to learn how to bake bread. Sadly, my bread machine sprung a leak and all my water leaked out of the pan into the machine.

But I still wanted to make this bread!

I used all the ingredients; as is. And I hand kneaded them in a bowl, let it rise, punched it down, flattened it, folded it up and put into a greased loaf pan. I then let it rise a second time. 

I preheated my oven to 350 degrees and let it bake for 30 minutes. Inserted a meat thermo and at 200 degrees, it was done. I let it rest for 10 minutes and then sliced into it (because I wanted to eat it, darnit!)

It was/is FANTASTIC!! Even my Husband loves it! I could not be more thrilled! I thought for sure since I didn't use a bread maker, somehow it wouldn't turn out. I am SO SO glad I went ahead and made it anyway!

I DO suggest that when hand kneading it, you do not put int he extra 1/2 teaspoon of salt. It isn't needed.

text:
I just got Zojirushi bread machine and baked first white bread which we enjoyed. But as one viewer mentioned earlier, it was dense(it's ok by me)but got harder so quick.  So I found this recipe and gave a try this morning.  I used exact ingredients except I used 2 1/4 tsp  active dry yeast from the jar that I had(2 1/4 tsp=1 package) and olive oil instead of veg oil.
I also liked this recipe when I read it because it uses 1 tsp salt unlike machine recipe calls for 2 tsp.  The reason I wanted bake a bread at home started because most of store bought bread was salty or too sweet for me.

What a fantastic home made bread machine baked!!!!
Not only it looks tasty but was soft bread I have always dreamed of baking.  Unlike others mentioned that bread was too soft to slice,   my bread was soft but I sliced perfect slice immediately after taking out of machine with a ordinary bread cutting knife.  
It was the best bread I ever baked!!!
I am proud to recommend this recipe to anyone who loves to bake and eat it too.  
Thank you"shecooks2" very much for posting this recipe. I am lucky to say I found the perfect recipe before I make too many mistake.

text:
Wow! Like many other reviewers have said, I've never had bread machine that tasted this great. This is my first review I've written on Allrecipes after a couple years of being on here, that's how great it is. It doesn't even taste like all the other dense and flavorless bread machine bread I've had before. I thought that was just how bread machine bread had to turn out and there was no way around it. This amazingly soft, airy, delicate, perfect bread is the answer to that. I do like a more yeasty flavor to my bread, and while this has more yeasty flavor than when I put the yeast in last, maybe I'll try a sponge in the future to see if that works. If anyone has done that please write your tips!

I found this recipe last night and I'm currently making my 2nd loaf, just as the recipe is written (and using olive oil instead of vegetable oil and the 1 1/2 tsp of salt everyone has recommended.) After that loaf I'm going to try someones recommendations of adding 1/2 tsp of each: garlic powder, oregano, basil and thyme; adding them to the salt. My first loaf was made at the 1 1/2lb setting, and it came out looking like a 2 lb loaf. I'm emailing this recipe to everyone I know who has a bread machine!

text:
Great recipe! I started it in the bread machine just to find that my bread machine doesn't work.I dissolved the yeast in 1 cup of warm water then added the oil and the mixed the dry ingredients together before adding to the water and oil.I put it in the kitchenaid mixer for about 10 mins with the dough hook..put it in a pre-greased bread pan and covered it with saran wrap and a towel and let rise for maybe a half hour and it had risen very nice.I baked it at 350 for about 40 -45 mins and immediately brushed butter on the top to soften it...it tastes wonderful and the top is nice and soft and the middle is very soft but nicely formed.Thanks for sharing!!

userID:

Display Name:
Tunaoue

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As others mentioned, my bread machine instructions suggest adding yeast as the last ingredient but it does mention that it's okay not to; that proofing the yeast will not affect the outcome. I'm not as experienced as some bakers here, but I have done dozens of loaves and was constantly experimenting with the bread machine.  I found that using the machine as the kneading tool to produce a glob of dough and then transfer it to bread pans works best for me. I had developed my own recipe based on this one, some others on this site and other sites and ultimately from the results of my "what-ifs"     
    1/4 cup warm water
    3/4 cup warm milk
    1/3 cup white sugar
    1 package active dry yeast (2-1/4 tspn) 
    1 egg, slightly beaten
    1/3 cup butter, softened or liquid

    3 3/4 cups all-purpose flour
    1-1/2 teaspoon salt 

Combining the warm water & milk with sugar and letting it sit for 10 min gets the yeast started really well.  Subbing margarine or veggie oil for the butter works okay, but butter adds to the final flavor. I also add one egg which increases the total liquid content which is adjusted for with the increased flour.  Let rise for an hour (ish) and bake at 400 F for 12-15 min -- OR let the bread machine do the baking.

text:
An excellent light, tender & flavorful loaf. This recipe is very close to the Foccacia (sp?) bread recipe I've used for years, which I use for loaves, soft bread sticks, pizza dough & sometimes hard rolls. The differences are: 1 Tbsp less of oil & sugar, bread flour instead of regular flour & the yeast isn't proofed in mine. My bread machine calls for the dry ingredients to be put in first, followed by the wet but this is easily solved by dissolving the sugar & yeast in the water & allowing the yeast to proof outside of the machine.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
If I can give this recipe a 10-star, I will. I have been baking this bread ever since I can remember. I had tried baking other breads before while I was looking for a good one to bake everytime but this one comes up trumps every single time!

Apart from the basic suggested ingredients and instructions, I also added the other suggestions in the the review like adding 1 and 1/4 tsp of salt. I also am not comfortable with cooking with my bread machine so after it finished it's job in the dough department I take it out and knead a little and rise it again to bake in the oven. What I did differently is that the moment my dough start mixing, I add a cup of either provel cheese or cheddar. When the dough comes out of the machine, risen and ready to bake, I slice the top a little bit then rub melted butter on top. I put it in the oven with a pan of water on the lower rack, bake the bread for 5 minutes, take it out and add some more cheese toppings or roasted sesame seeds. Black sesame seeds are good too. Since there are only two of us here usually in the house, I make 4 mini loaves instead one big one. Yesterday I made those little loaves again for a neighbour for his birthday. The whole family loves it! His son even took one home with him. That was the nicest compliment ever. I really love this bread. I am making a batch today for me and my husband as he loves having my bread instead of the bought one. Thank you so much for this recipe. We really love this one.

text:
I just got a bread machine, and I've tried this recipe three times. No luck! And I was so inspired by all the great reviews too. I will keep trying, but I'm a novice bread maker so I'm sure I screwed something up somewhere. Maybe it was the oil I used? Twice safflower and once olive - I don't use soybean or canola, your typical vegetable oils.  I'm only giving this two starts, and that's because of my three loaves, the one that was the best did really taste good. All three of them caved in, and I did increase the salt. One time I used honey instead of sugar, one time I thought the water wasn't warm enough....it's disappointing, especially when so many of the other reviewers so easily made modifications. I will not give up!

Okay...notes on loaf #4. Decreased water by one T, added one T of vital wheat gluten. It seemed to work. I left in the machine too long after it was done so the crust was a bit overdone for me but the rest of it is really good!

I don't do it in a bread machine (don't own one), but, I have found this to be a good and simple loaf to throw together quickly. I mix it up in my kitchen aide, takes about 10-12 minutes from start to putting in it the bowl to rise. I do add in other grains to boost the nutrition value (ww fl, flax, teff, spelt, oats, barley, etc). Turns out well. I love that I can get it kneaded up and rising while I'm still getting my kids ready for school. It doesn't take a lot of babysitting, which is a definite plus for me!

text:
I have been making this for years, and it's the method (proof yeast in water) I use for all breads in my bread machine.

My machine makes a 2 or 2.5lb loaf.  I adjust the servings from 12 to 16 for a 2bl loaf.  Never fails.

I made the original recipe (12 servings) on the 2lb loaf setting once and it wasn't good.  Dense, didn't rise.  I wonder if the people who are having trouble are using the wrong recipe size for their machine loaf size?

This recipe is perfect! Every other bread machine recipe I've used has created a short, dense, heavy loaf that tasted decent. country:
None
text:
Like many others I was really hesitant to ignore the many warnings to not proof the yeast when using a bread machine. But I've been really bummed to not be able to make a light fluffy loaf for sandwiches, so I was desperate. I'm so glad I tried it! I don't cook with vegetable oil so I subbed olive oil, and I added 1/2 tsp of salt as recommended by others.   I set my machine to 1.5 lb loaf, white bread cycle, medium crust. It looked perfect at about 5 minutes left on the timer, so I turned it off. I have a perfect loaf, soft and fluffy inside, flaky on the outside. I was worried it would get smashed when I sliced it but as long as you use a nice sharp bread knife, it'll be okay. So happy to have found this recipe!

text:
An update to my post: I do NOT add additional salt, rather I am careful not to allow the salt to get into the yeast mixture before I start the machine.  I make a little cavity in the flour to add the salt - excellent results every time! great loaves!

I have tried a variety of bread recipes to find one with a rich texture, moist center, and sturdy crust - this recipe gives all of that AND tastes great! A new staple for my home to replace the additives and preservatives of store bought bread!

text:
This bread was really great! My 4 mo old daughter has a dairy sensitivity, and so I am having to prepare my own everything, and this bread hit the spot. I subbed olive oil for vegetable oil, and added 1/2 tsp salt based on other reviews. I then baked in the oven instead of the bread machine (because I have never made a good loaf cooked in the machine). The taste is wonderful, it will make perfect sandwiches and toast. I am planning to make a cinnamon loaf today, by adding cinnamon sugar at the end of the dough cycle when you normally add nuts and things. I am so happy to have a dairy free bread that is SO easy to make! Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
We are not big bread eaters, but I was looking for something easy to make and this bread is it!  Don't be intimidated by going against the grain and proofing the yeast first, as this will not alter the end result.  I followed a previous reviewer's comments to use 1/2 cup whole wheat flour and 2 1/2 cups bread flour, and I used 3 Tbsp. sugar.  This was the easiest recipe for bread I have found, and my kids asked for seconds (they never did before), so this will become a new staple in our house.  Thanks!

text:
Well, 3rd time is a charm!  The first time I made this bread, I was using questionable yeast and I forgot the salt.  It rose but was pretty blah.  The second time, I remembered the salt so it tasted better but for some reason I split it into 2 pans instead of one and got some pretty short loaves.  (I just made the dough in the breadmaker and baked it in the oven.)  Tonight was try #3 and I came out with a BEAUTIFUL loaf of yummy bread!  I will be using this recipe to replace store bought bread!  I used 1 1/4 tsp of salt and olive oil pers some suggestions and I used 1 1/2 C bread flour and 1 1/2 C whole wheat flour.  YUMMY!  Thanks so much for posting!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was fabulous!! I've used a bread maker for 15 years and tried lots of recipes.  This one is a keeper.  I have a Zojirushi bread machine and haven't been happy with the recipes that were recommended with it.  They all would be dense or actually fall and would make nice doorstops.  Based on all the recommendations for this recipe I tried it yesterday.  I scaled it up to 16 servings for a 2lb loaf, and I shouldn't have!  It rose right up to the window.  And it didn't brown like it should have but I think that was because the loaf was so big that the warm air couldn't circulate correctly to brown the top.  But the loaf itself is light and tasty.  DO dissolve the yeast into the water and sugar.  I increased the salt like others suggested.  I might try to decrease the sugar a bit as I try to stay away from white sugar.  But this loaf ended up being so big I didn't have a bread bag that would fit around it.  AMAZING!

text:
my breadmaker had been confined to the shed thanks to the brick like results it produced with that irritating paddle hole at the bottom.  then I found this recipe for best bread machine bread, and  the breadmaker was restored to the kitchen for one last chance.  now,   the family love this bread   I make it to the recipe in the breadmaker  but use 'dough' setting, then bang it into a bread tin,  there is enough dough for a small round loaf as well, [which I cook in a soup dish] leave to rise  place in the oven which has been heated to gas regulo 8 immediately turning down the heat to reg. 6 and bake for around 30-40 mins.   wow a success  with home baked bread at last  no more commercially produced bread for us, thank you.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2009-12-01T23:40:39.023
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4268910
Display Name:
TexasDad
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
46
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like everyone else, this is the best recipe ever. I made only one change which was to use olive oil instead of canola or vegetable oil. Long story short, it literally was pushing the top of the bread maker up, not just touching the window. That gave me an idea. I used the dough setting instead. After 1 hour 30 min, I poured the dough out onto a floured surface, punched it down, and filled a commercial 10 inch loaf pan I got from Sur La Table. I let it rise for forty minutes in my oven with some warm water in it that raised the temp to a stable 84 degrees. At the end of that time, it had more than doubled, but, was still just shy of a standard commercial loaf's footprint. I took out the water and set the oven to 380 degrees, in the approx ten minutes to hit 380, it finished rising to the footprint of a standard store bought commercial loaf. From that point it hit the oven beeped me that it hit the 380 degree setting, I gave it another 25 to 30 minutes to finish. What I get out of it is fantastic bread I can use in my son's school lunches that uses olive oil instead of the cheap oils they use in standard white bread. I get the benefits of serving him a perfect loaf of unbleached flour and olive oil. He gets the benefit of great tasting bread he loves and will eat. Also, when I add a 1 tsp of unchopped rosemary or 1/2 tsp of ground rosemary, I get an incredible loaf for either left over turkey sandwiches or an egg salad sandwich.

text:
Like some others, I was skeptical about not following the manufacturers directions for making bread in my bread machine.  I took the risk and it came out fine.  What puzzles me is what all the raving reviews are  about.  The bread tastes just like most of the breads I've made before.  Have none of these people ever produced bread like this from their machines?  It was good, but tastes just like all the other breads I've been making for years.  Also, several people mentioned how huge the loaf was.  Mine was normal in size (or at least what I consider normal)  Perhaps their machines don't make very generous sized loafs?
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-11-24T11:29:33.79
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4143441
Display Name:
DianeP
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
104
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have had my Breadman TR2700 for 3 days and I am on my 6th loaf using this recipe.  Every loaf has come out perfect!  The best idea is to proof the yeast prior to adding the other ingredients. I used the med crust setting for the 1 1/2# white bread, baking time 3:05.  This is what I did because I did not have all the "bread machine" flour or yeast onhand.  I mixed 3/4c 2% Milk with 1/4 c water and 2 tablespoons sugar in a glass and microwaved until warm (110degrees). I stirred liquid and poured into pan that was placed in bread machine.  I took 2 teaspoons of Fleischmanns Active Dry Yeast and sprinkled on top of liquid.  Close the lid and let proof for 10 min. In a mixing cup I measured 1/4 canola oil and added 1 1/2 teas salt.  After the 10 minutes, pour the oil and salt into yeast mixture and then add 2 3/4 cup all purpose flour using a measuring cup so the flour is evenly dispursed over the mixture. Close the lid and hit start.  Set it and forget it. UMM UMM  My family inhales this bread  (do not use this proofing method for "delay" baking)  Thanks Diggetydog !!

I've been successfully baking bread by hand for years, but have never been able to get a decent loaf out of my automatic bread machine.  I wasn't really expecting this one to turn out any better, but I was wrong!  I followed the recipe exactly as written, and it turned out perfectly!  And I don't think it could be any easier. Display Name:
PEARLYVICTORIA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe should be called the Oh My Gosh Bread! It is the first loaf of bread from my Breadman that I consider perfect. The crust is flaky and delicious. I didn't have either bread flour or bread machine yeast so I used active dry yeast and unbleached flour with no problems. The only mistake I made was starting too late which meant I was eating warm bread at 8:30 PM and had to try to sleep with that wonderful, fresh baked bread aroma floating through the house! I also used the British measurement for the flour as I had already made two loaves from another recipe that were dense and useless. Sure enough, the 3 cups weighed 400 grams. Follow the mixing instructions without fear, it works! 4/23/09, I made this recipe for the third time. It seems to be even more perfect this time! I added an additional 1/2 tsp salt but think I will cut that down to 1/4 tsp. I also used rapid rise yeast. No problem. I don't know why others are having difficulties. All I know is that I weigh my flour by first fluffing it with a whisk each time before I lightly spoon it into the measuring cup. Then I put it in the container for the scale. If it is measured properly it should equal 400gms. Also added an additional tablespoon of sugar. An amazing recipe. Simply amazing.

I am a first time bread machine user...LITERALLY! I just bought a bread machine 2 nights ago, and this was the first recipe that I made in it. Raised by my grandma, I actually learned the fine arts of bread making (especially therapeutic after an argument/disagreement with your hubby!) This recipe was against everything I knew about making bread, so I was really concerned about how it would turn out, PLUS it was my first time using my bread machine. I pulled up a chair and watched (almost all 3 hours!! LOL) I was amazed to see how everything came together, and produced a WONDERFUL loaf of bread!! This is the only white bread recipe I'll be using!! Absolutely excellent flavor, texture, and aroma for the ease of this recipe!  (BTW...I joined this site JUST to rate and review this recipe! LOL)

text:
The Best! I've tried this in 3 different manufacturers bread machines with great results everytime. (My mom and my friend both have diffrent machines than I do). I made this recipe the first time I ever used a bread machine and it will be the only recipe I use. I had to adjust my crust to a light setting as medium was too crispy for me - but that is a personal choice - other than that I use this recipe just as it is written (use bread flour and 2 1/2 tespoons yeast) no need to change anything. Turnes out excellent! It even got my boyfriend into making bread (and he won't admit to cooking..hahaha)! The lightest, highest, nicest loaf of bread I've seen come from a bread machine (tasts just like mom's). Thank-you for sharing this recipe.

Just got my first bread machine as a xmas gift.  I've been trying different recipes and nothing seems to come out to my liking.  Either the bread is too dense, too dry, or just plain not good.  This recipe made me want to actually keep my bread machine.  The bread was delicious.  I cut into about after 20 minutes of cooling time.  It was light and not too airy and had some chew to it.  The crust was crunchy on the sides and the top was a bit flaky.  Mmm..mm..good.  I'll forget about all the other white bread recipes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the recipe should be modified to use regular yeast and not the "rapid rise" bread machine yeast.  For my first loaf I used regular yeast and followed the instructions to the letter.  Bread came out great.  For my second loaf I tried using bread machine yeast AKA rapid rise.  This resulted in a loaf that over rose in the machine.  For my third, I tried out the "rapid" option on my breadmaker to see if this setting would help.  While the bread did not rise as much, it still touched the top of the machine a little bit.  This recipe probably does not need to "proof" the yeast and can probably be used with the regular instructions for your bread machine.  It does make a nice tasting loaf of bread and I loathe to add more salt to a recipe (I'm sensitive).  I would recommend just regular yeast instead of the more expensive bread machine yeast.

text:
This bread was phenomenal! I have used bread machine mixes in the past, and was always somewhat disappointed with the reseults. The top would fall in, or it just would be an average loaf. This loaf was picture perfect, and was a bit more dense, so it didn't fall apart when I was cutting it. I added 1/2 tsp more salt, and I had jar yeast which said to use 1/2 tsp per cup of flour, so I only used 1.5 tsp of instant yeast. Thank you so much for this recipe, now, instead of spending $2-$3 per loaf by using a mix I can make many more for a lot less, and its better bread!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have just found my new bread recipe! I have always struggled to find a recipe for my machine that did not end up drying out after the first slice was cut. This recipe yields a nice, light, yet substantial loaf of bread that actually stays soft once it is cut! I made only a couple of changes - I substituted 2 tablespoons of sorghum + 1 tablespoon of Demerara (evaporated cane juice) for the sugar, 2 1/4 tsp. bread machine yeast (the type in the jar), 1 cup bread flour, 1 cup whole wheat flour, 1 cup ground oatmeal (milled in the food processor), 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt. The sponge seemed sticky while it was cycling, but I resisted the urge to modify. We got a nice, fluffy, chewy loaf of bread that is now on the verge of being gone less than 24 hours later! Despite the addition of whole grains, the bread was not coarse or chunky. LOVE IT!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AWESOME!  I am so happy I found this recipe.  I received my bread maker for Xmas two years ago.  I made a couple loafs with the recipe provided by the manufacturer.  Both were dense and just not at all pleasant.  I put it away and kind of forgot about it.  

Well, with the bread prices for store bought bread going up and up, I decided it was time to break out the ole' bread machine out and give it another go with a different recipe.  

This recipe is awesome!  I can't believe how light and fluffy this bread came out.  Absolutely delicious.  I was kind of nervous, but it seems this recipe is fool proof.  This is the only bread my family eats now.

The only tip I have is make sure you use warm water, not hot.  Hot water can actually kill the yeast.  I didn't know that and used hot water the first time I made this.  It still came out good, but it's much better with warm water.

text:
I used this recipe to break in my new bread machine and it turned out perfect.  Great overall texture with a nice lightly crisped crust and very soft inside.  I did increase my salt to 1.5 teaspoons as others suggested (thanks) and I used melted butter in place of the oil.  I just the bread to make the best warm cheese sandwich.  I microwaved the entire sandwich for about thirty seconds and the bread kepts it crispy crust and the inside just got softer.

Definitely a recipe I'll make again and again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Favorite very versatile recipe for my dairy/egg allergic kids.  We often sub in up to 1 1/2 cups naturally white whole wheat flour from King Arthur for part of the flour.  Sub up to 3 Tablespoons brown sugar for white sugar.  Found that 1 1/2 teaspoons salt keep the bread from rising and hitting the top of our Cuisinart convection bread maker.  We've done up to 20 variations with very few problems.  Great base recipe.  Makes a nice raisin bread with raisins added after initial mix and extra yeast to handle the cinamin and sugar.

text:
I am sorry to say this was a little disapointing for me. I found that it was too much yeast for a bread machine. My loaf was riseing out of the pan with 1.5 hours left in the cycle. (Maybe thats a machine error, I am not sure. I ended up removing it form the machine and baked it off in the oven. It did have great texture and made a beautiful loaf. It just had no flavor. My family is used to yeast breads made with scaled milk and just didn't care for this one.

This is a great recipe that I have made several times now.  It is as basic as basic gets yet still has a nice consistency...not too heavy and not too light.  Being on a farm I don't always have the time or inclination to run to town for a loaf of bread and this recipe is the one I use for an all around loaf that makes great sandwiches as well as a great fresh accompaniment to my pot roasts and other hearty farm meals.

text:
This bread is delicous! It was the first bread recipe I tried in the bread machine that I got for Christmas! It came out exactly as described! Flaky crust and chewy, moist center. The only recommendation I have to make is to use an electric knife when slicing.. Or take the advice of the other rates and lower the amount of yeast..Its hard to cut without breaking it apart. But we used the electric knife and it turned out so pretty! Just like store bought :) I'll use this again.

text:
WOW! Even a non-baker can make perfect bread! I haven't used my bread machine in years, but my family was asking for some home baking, so I gave this a try. I have the old 1 lb loaf cylinder machine, so I used the "scaling" option and put in 8 servings instead of the 12 listed. It was in perfect proportion- a beautiful golden top rising just above the rim! It just came out of the machine and I am starting another loaf right away! My yeast packets were "expired", I had to use margarine spread (2 1/2x as much due to water content) and it STILL came out PERFECT!! If I can do it, ANYONE can-thank you for this great recipe!!!
