text:
As I was making this bread I wasn't sure how many teaspoons were equal to .25 ounces. I used a shot glass (which wasn't exactly the best measuring tool) and estimated it at 2 teaspoons. Later I did the conversion and it actually should have been 1.5 teaspoons. I ended up with a mushroom loaf! Also, I used the traditional active dry yeast instead of the bread machine yeast so I think the next time I will stick with the recommended 1.5 tsp of the bread machine yeast. The bread was soft in the middle and crusty on the outside and it made a really crunchy toast.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/17798.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the whitest white bread I have ever made.  LOL  It was great except next time I would turn my machine on during those first ten minutes with just the yeast.  The first several minutes on my machine it just sits there preheating and what not so I think the extra delay made my bread not as perfectly shaped as it could have been.  Put the water yeast and sugar in, turn it on and put a timer on for ten minutes so when it's up just quickly add the other stuff.  Someone here said it was bland and it is, but that makes it perfect for putting flavored anything on it, just butter or jam or making it garlic bread...  You could do anything with this, it is a perfect basic bread.  The crust was flaky-good and the whole family loved it.

This bread turned out pretty well.  It rose to a perfect level.  The crust is good - but not as crispy or flaky as I would have liked.  My only actual problem with this bread was the flavor. 10 Stars!! Just the best bread recipe ever. 
I use 2-1/2 tsp of yeast & Hollywood oil & it comes out perfect.  I have baked it in the machine & also take it out & let it rise in a 9x5 pan for 30 minutes & bake at 350º for 30 minutes.
I read ever review & have to thank KWEHRHAN on 4-4-02 & BERMYROSE on 11-10-03 for their suggestions.  The peperoni bread was great for a dinner with a salad.  The bread made with 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour was also wonderful.  Plan to e-mail all my friends with this recipe.

I am a big bread machine user.  I make bread in mine almost everyday and can honestly say this is a GREAT recipe. You wouldn't think that a few little techniques would make any difference, but the crust on this is light and thin, much like bread in the oven.  Usually bread machine bread crust is hard and thick and we slice it off.  Not with this recipe!  Try it!  It is yummy.  Three of us ate the entire loaf for dinner.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve been making breadmaker bread for 30+ years, in a succession of different machines, using every conceivable recipe—but of course always following the manufacturers’ instructions when putting in those ingredients. Wound up with some tasty stuff, but a leathery crust and dense, spongy texture always made it obvious it came from a machine. This produced a perfect loaf, with a light, airy crumb and a crisp, flaky crust that makes that perfect sound when you bite it. Made as directed except followed other reviewers’ advice and upped salt to 1-1/2 teaspoons. Will never make another bread machine bread without proofing the yeast.

text:
I followed the advice of other reviewers and reduced the amount of yeast by 1/4 tsp. and increased the amount of salt by a scant tsp.  I also measured the temp. of my water to ensure that it was not too hot and not too cool, added it to the yeast and sugar and waited for the foaming and bubbling.  The loaf was perfectly sized, a nice medium crust (as per my bread machine setting) with a tender white center.  This will be my go-to bread recipe.  I never want to buy bread again.  My family agrees!  Thanks for a great, simple recipe and all the wonderful hints and suggestions.

None
text:
Instead of using cups as a measurement for flour I weighed my flour instead. 1 cup = 128 g (384g total for this recipe). Then I used Red Star Instant dry yeast but referring to the instructions of 1/2 tsp per cup of flour used (1.5 tsp total for this recipe). Lastly, instead of 1 tsp salt I used 1.5 tsp salt.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would have to agree.  This is a pretty great recipe!  We have decided to bake all our own bread so we have been experimenting with several bread machine recipes lately and my kids declared this the winner.  I followed the recipe as written with the exception of adding a pinch more salt as some have suggested.  I set the machine for a 1.5lb loaf and medium crust.  Turned out perfect for sandwiches, etc.  I think I’ll try light crust next time with a little honey to see how that makes up.  One note: I didn’t let the yeast proof as the recipe instructs.  Since I was using active dry yeast, I just added it when I put the flour in.  This is such a straightforward recipe, I’m planning on premixing the dry ingredients for several loaves in separate mason jars and keeping them on hand so I can quickly make new loaves.  Just add the warm water, oil and then the premix to the machine and have bread ready to bake in less than 2 minutes!

text:
In my mind, I knew this technique would work in my new machine, but being new to the bread machine world, I used the manufacturer's recipe. My two previous attempts just did not give the results I expected.  Every recipe I researched said the same thing, but then I came across this simple recipe...
 In my opinion, it completely shattered the  the myth of how I must use my bread machine!   
I made one slight change.  I used melted butter instead of oil.  I also added in a little additional softened butter during the the  "Add Mix-Ins" kneading cycle with about a teaspoon of extra flour).  The experimental loaf turned out excellent.  I could smell the difference as it was baking.  I love yeast bread and this did not disappoint.  It rose higher and the texture is so incredibly soft and the butter gives it a brioche-like flavor.

text:
Made my first load. Followed one of the Ladies suggestions and added the 1/2 tsp of salt to the ingredients and the loaf cake out nicely. Only problem even completely cooled down the next morning it was really difficult to cut the bread with my bread knife and I have an Oster knife block set that is new and sharp so it isn’t the knife. I did the warm but not too warm water, sugar and yeast. Let it sit for 10 minutes and it bubbles up beautifully. Then I added my bread flour, oil, and 1 1/2  tsp of salt.  I have a brand new Hamilton Beach bread machine and the settings were on: Basic, Medium color, and 1 1/2 lb loaf. I think I did everything right??!!  DID I do something wrong?   I am right this minute making a second loaf of this bread. I have my toes crossed that the second time around it comes out better!!  If it counts my Mom loves the bread and she’s made homemade bread, kneading by hand, all my life and was sooo skeptical about the bread machine!!  Thanks for the recipe it was super fun to do I just hope I didn’t screw it up, TWICE!!  lol

text:
So i am new to a bread machine, and the first few loaves i made, i followed the recipes that came with it.  meh.   Not what i thought it would be like.  i was disappointed to say the least.  Then i found this recipe.   I made it exactly as is the first time, but we have a mini bread maker, so it was a lil too much.   All i did was cut out 1 cup of flour and OMG, this bread is now to die for!!   I was also afraid to go against the mfr direction of not allowing any liquid to touch the yeast.  Trust me, it makes a big difference.   throw those rules out the window!

userID:
24101984
Display Name:
Kat M
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
18
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5662432.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With bread like this, who needs the store-bought stuff!?
I used all-purpose flour (I live in Canada, and the all-purpose flour we have here is high enough in gluten to make bread. Of course, if you have the real bread flour, go for it, but if you don't, no problem.)
Also, I stuck to 1 tsp of salt for the recipe, even though some reviewers mentioned they increased it. I had no problems with it rising (it rose very high) and it tastes quite salty as is. 
Also, I used half olive oil, half vegetable oil, but I don't think it makes any difference in the taste. Furthermore, I don't know why one reviewer mentioned not to use canola oil. I've used it for breads before and never had an issue. 
This is definitely my new go-to bread machine recipe. Yum!
Review:

text:
Best recipe I have found for bread machine white bread.  It will be my go to recipe!  I increased the sugar to 3 tablespoons and was nervous leaving the yeast to rest in the sugar water for 10 minutes.  It was very frothy,  but did not seem to make the bread more dense.  I wonder if it would have risen more uniformly (it coned up in the middle) if the yeast had not been so active when I added the dry ingredients.  I enjoyed the texture and the flavor.

text:
I received a bread machine for Christmas this year and decided to browse online for bread recipes.  When I found this recipe and read through several reviews I decided to give it a try - I really wanted a "win" for my first try with the machine. Unfortunately, it was the 2nd loaf that was a "win" (I messed up the yeast measurements in the 1st loaf).  I have now made 4 perfectly delicious loaves (following the recipe exactly) and my family LOVES it.  I see no reason to even bother with the recipes in the manual.  I think I'm ready to start experimenting with flavors, etc.  Thank you SO much for this great recipe and for making my 1st try at baking my own bread a success!  I also thank all of the reviewers for taking the time to post - 2k reviews is the reason I chose this as my first (and only) bread recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made variations of this bread three times in the last week. 1st loaf- stayed true the recipe but increased the salt by a 1/2 tsp as recommended in the reviews, also used melted butter in place of oil...phenomenal! This loaf did collapse a tad on the top right at the end. 2nd loaf- same as first 1st but made with olive oil, 1/2 c white wheat flour, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp. Italian seasoning and 1 cup shredded cheddar-  so good and never collapsed!!! the 3rd as been my favorite by far... I wanted to experiment with a healthier grain bread. I followed other reviews to decrease yeast, while increasing sugar. Used only 2 tsp yeast, 3 tablespoons honey, 1 1/4 c white wheat flour, olive oil and added 2 tbsp flax seed, chopped walnuts and pumpkin seeds to the batter. I also let the last one rise at room temp for an hour then baked at 375 for 30 minutes! Sprinkled oat bran and oats on top! SO AMAZING IN EVERY WAY! I liked the increased sugar, less yeast variation just as much. Such a simple, and obviously flexible and forgiving base to use. Will be trying a cinnamon raisin on next!

text:
I substituted 1/4 cup of butter instead of using oil, added the recommended extra half teaspoon of salt for total of 1-1/2 teaspoons . I also did not have to let the yeast sit 10 minutes in water since I use "Bread machine" aka Instant yeast.  I used #2 on my machine since this is a 1-1/2 lb loaf, finished in 3 hours. The bread rose nice and fluffy without any big holes in it. The texture was perfect, I sliced some thin slices this morning to make toast, better than store bought!  I think next I will substitute some wheat flour for part of the white flour as I prefer wheat bread. This is my new recipe for bread, not having to buy dry milk for the bread machine recipes is great! Thanks for sharing this with us.

text:
As written, it was an epic failure. My bread machine says never let the water touch the yeast. Other reviews said ignore that and follow the directions. I followed the directions exactly and ended up with a cooked flour blob. I followed the recipe again with the exact same ingredients, only I disregarded the first step and put the ingredients in the typical bread machine way - water, oil, sugar, flour, salt, yeast (in that order). THAT yields a perfect sandwich bread.  3 stars because the ingredients are spot on.  Knocking two down for the misleading bubble yeast step that wasted a bunch of ingredients.

text:
This simple recipe has been my go to bread recipe for years. Here are some tips:

I use 2 teaspoons of bread machine (instant) yeast. The recipe calls for one packet (2  1/2 tsp) of yeast. I find that this causes the bread to rise too much and then collapse.

Once I adjusted the yeast, it's perfect every time!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Been using this recipe for years as is. A couple tips.... no matter what your bread machine instructions say, do the yeast, sugar and water first as explained above. I dissolve the sugar into the warm water by stirring and agitate it occasionally after I put the yeast in to make sure the mixture has a really good frothy start (important). One more thing, but very important... WEIGH the 3 cups of flour in (12.75 oz). Everyone loves this bread and it does comes out perfect every time! I use the “white” setting on bread machine with medium crust usually. Also leave it be till it’s done, it takes only a small shock at the wrong time to make the whole loaf fall!

I've made this and variations based on it several times in the last few weeks. One thing I've changed is I've added an additional 1/4 cup of water and at times have not added the ingredients right at 10 minutes of yeasting. In either case, it has been excellent.

One other alternative that I've done is split whole wheat yeast with regular bread yeast (1.5 cups each) for some excellent wheat bread.

text:
These directions are awful.  I made this and the bread come out as hard as a rock.   I found out from my sister who has a bread maker that you are NOT supposed to add the yeast to the water.  You add the yeast last after you add the flour.  You create a hole at the top of the flour and add the yeast.  thanks a lot of wasting my money!

text:
Can't believe how pretty and soft this loaf was.  I added 1/2 tsp extra salt and needed to add extra water as it was stiff in the machine.  I let the machine do the work, then transfer dough to my own bread pan and let it rise a third time before baking at 375*, then lower to 350* for 35 minutes.  I used store brand flour and yeast and it was perfect.  Can't wait to try my luck again.  This is a winner along with my Pinterest recipe that uses pricy King Arthur flour and yeast.  Both do well in the bread machine.  I'm not a fan of baking in the machine, I always bake it in the oven.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Very simple. I've made it both with 1 tsp and 1.5 tsp of salt. Both work well. I prefer to finish in the oven. Turns out much nicer and I brush it with butter while hot out of the oven. If your machine has a dough setting, simply turn it out on a floured surface, flatten into a rectangle, fold into thirds, rotate it 90 degrees and into thirds again.  Place it seam side down into a greased pan, cover with damp cloth and let it rise for 1 to 1.5 hr. Preheat oven to 350 and bake 30 minutes or to an internal tempreture of 190 degrees.  Remove from pan and cool on a wire rack.

text:
Great bread.  Made with equal measures of Wheat Montana Premium All Purpose Flour (High in protein so works in bread machine and is sold in Walmart) and  with whole wheat flour.  I threw in a tablespoon each of flax and poppy seed.  And I followed the directions of putting the yeast and sugar in warm water for 10 minutes and it worked.  I used the dough cycle and put in loaf pan 45 minutes to rise and then baked at 350* for 35 minutes.. As others have said, this will be my go to recipe as it could easily be changed up a bit with herbs and spices.

text:
I've had a bread machine tucked away on a top shelf for years. Got tired of paying $3.00 for a decent loaf of bread, only to have to store it in the fridge or lose it to mold within 4 days or so. Got the machine down and came across this recipe. 

It is THE BOMB. I've made it about 6 times so far, making sure to wrap it in a layer of parchment then foil while warm to keep it soft. I love it! The only thing I changed was adding just a few more drops of oil before the final kneading. That's all it needs.

text:
This recipe created a beautiful loaf of bread!  Like one of the other reviewers, I set my bread machine on the dough cycle because I wanted to bake the bread in a loaf pan.  The dough was absolutely perfect and baked in the oven (with a pan of water on the base of the oven) at 350 degrees for 25 minutes. I can't wait to bake more loaves and experiment with a variety of flours and ingredients!

text:
The secret is to allow the yeast to foam for 10 minutes with the hot water and sugar. Then measure the ingredients correctly. This is toooooo easy and sooooo good. I noticed that spoke bread machines call for the yeast to go on top of the flour.  No. Foam the yeast and you'll get a perfect loaf in 3 hours.

text:
Like many of you I was reluctant to try this recipe as it goes directly against the instructions that came with my bread machine.  I decided to "throw caution to the wind" and make it.  The only thing I did differently is I used the "dough setting" and then allowed the bread to do its final rising in a bread pan before baking it in the oven at 375 degrees for 30 minutes.  The result was a lovely fluffy loaf of bread with a lovely crust.  My bread machine has a large pan and the bread that comes out of it is too big to fit in the toaster.  It's a million times better than the very dense loaf I was getting with the recipe that came with my bread machine.  This is absolutely the best loaf of bread I've gotten with my machine.  It's now my "go to" recipe for a loaf of delicious white bread.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is VASTLY improved with a few tweaks:

1.5 cups water instead of 1 cup
double the sugar amount and substitute honey
mix the warm water, honey and yeast in 1st and let  sit for 15-20 mins, then add the other ingredients and start.
most bread recipes can be improved with more water. a 33% water to flour ratio generally produces poor bread. 50% much better, you can go higher as well, experiment.

text:
I double the recipe for my 2lb bread machine

*Use the 2 lb setting, light crust and white bread setting*

I also use whole wheat flour instead of white flour

I use melted butter rather than veg oil (better flavor)

I add a little honey since the whole wheat flour needs more moisture than ap flour

This recipe is easy to "play" with and add things to... milk instead of water, butter/olive oil, honey.... it's very forgiving!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Makes a delicious and tender loaf of white bread.  Versatile recipe.  We've added all sorts of different spices and cheeses and it comes out delicious every time.  One thing we did do different was use ADY (Active Dry Yeast) and proof the yeast in the machine before adding the other ingredients making sure to add salt last, and increased salt to 1-1/2 tsp.  We have done this in the bread machine completely, just on dough cycle and proofed the second time in bread pan before baking, and in the kitchenaid mixer/bread pan.  No matter what, it's foolproof... as long as we proofed the yeast first.

text:
I have tried a ton of bread recipes for my bread maker & most have been a complete flop. I typically use a milk bread recipe that turns out every time but I wanted to have another basic to rotate with. The only reason I gave this 4 stars is because I did use some suggestions and altered a few things. I used honey in place of sugar (WIN!), used the 1.5 tsp of salt & I subbed EVOO for the vegetable oil. This turned out perfectly, very moist & tender. I love recipes like this where you can switch out a few things for your taste or shopping preferences and it still turns out well. I think flexible recipes are a must and I really appreciate the scientific reviews and reasons for adjustments, after all, baking is just science! Happy baking!

country:
None
text:
I made this today and it came out beautiful.  I did make a few changes but it was more along the lines of technique.  I did add about 1/3 tsp extra of salt because because I thought it needed it.  I did use canola oil because I never use vegetable oil(personal preference) with out a hitch.  Most importantly though is that  whenever I'm making yeast breads, I always use bottled water and never tap.  Too many additives in tap water that can cause a recipe to fail;  such as fluoride, chlorine, rust or hard water.  So with all that being said, this is the best bread recipe I've made.  Soft and fluffy.

text:
Just made this and it was pretty good... I just purchased an OLD breadman machine off Craigslist and failed 3 times using their own instructions/recipe.
  I finally had somewhat of a success with this recipe. I found a huge indentation on the top...So, it must have risen too much and fell...there was a big empty hole under the indentation. But, after cutting that part off...the rest was a beautiful quarter loaf. Pretty tasty, too.
 I had already decreased the yeast to 2 tsp and increased the sugar to 2 1/2Tbl and the salt to 1 1/2tsp. 
I'll have to decrease the yeast again as others have said to do but, increase the sugar to 3tbl and keep the salt the same.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3013022.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a nice recipe but the loaf had a tendency to fall.  I also don't use vegetable oil in my bread; I don't like the flavor.  The vegetable oil plus the water was way too much liquid for my machine, and too much liquid can make a loaf fall. So I substituted 1/2 of a stick of butter, cut into small pieces and mixed in with the flour, in place of the oil, and got a beautiful, smooth, high loaf that did not fall.

Display Name:
Liz VanHuss Bateman

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Only bread I ever really make anymore. I do have a few things to say. If you use QUICK bread settings (1hr I suggest doubling yeast or your bread will be denser and not quite firm at same time. Not the best setting). Second like you've read, add 1/2 tsp of salt or it won't be anything like it should be. Thirdly I have a home in the mountains 7,000 ft elevation. The water ratio is fine. But in my Dallas Texas home I need to eye ball it at first and always need to add a couple tbsp of water at a time to get it to mix. Usually 4-6 tbsp is enough and if it does get sticky I sprinkle a tiny bit of flour. But I don't get it completely mixed in my oster bread maker with out a little extra water. I have a 2 lb bread maker and this rises till it touches the glass. It's fluffy and yummy. And super easy for a family of five to scarf with a meal lol. It's THAT good. Yummmmm have it in the oven. Ow. Who needs glade plug ins when you have a bread maker???!!! :)

This recipe is so easy and I have ALWAYS had good results with it. One thing I change is that I make it in the dough cycle and then transfer it to a greased loaf pan and let it rise for 30 minutes. Then I bake it at 350 for about 30 minutes. My family inhales it! Our favorite way to eat it is with honey butter. Mix with a fork a half stick of room temp butter with 2 Tbl honey. Sooooo good!

text:
This is a good basic recipe, however I think you have to be careful not to add salt to the yeast mix (use one and a half total), because when I added a little and prepared it as the recipe said, I got a fluffy, tangled loaf that was hollowing, fallen, and more pull-apart then slice. I tried it again according to the bread machine and used kosher salt and t was perfect for slicing. I even subbed one cup of flour for white whole wheat and it has great texture.

text:
I don't know what went wrong...  Along with all of the other reviewers, I went against what the instruction book said.  I put the yeast, water and honey (instead of sugar) in, left it froth for 10 minutes, then added the other ingredients and set it on white.  It came out dense and very short - the height of a regular loaf of bread, rather than as tall as the pan (like other breads).  I increased the salt to 1.5 tsp, since a reviewer said something about doing that because of the tendency to fall, and I did add a tablespoon of butter like another reviewer said.  It tastes good, but is definitely not light and fluffy.

I love this recipe. I adjusted salt to 1&1/2 tsp as precious review suggested. I also added 2t honey to the mix because I was looking for a sweeter breakfast bread, and reduced yeast to 2&1/8 t to counteract the way the honey caused the bread to rise the top of the machine.  Overall we love the taste and texture of this recipe. It makes me hesitant to go back to the bread machine instructions at all, since this works so well.

text:
Best recipe I have tried. It differs from the bread machine instructions to include yeast with the other dry ingredients. I haven't had good luck with other recipes, but this is easy and makes a delicious loaf. I find 2 teaspoons fresh yeast is plenty because apparently you don't want to over yeast. Also, I use 2-3 tablespoons sugar and find it doesn't matter if all purpose or bread flour. Sometimes I sprinkle some cinnamon in with the flour for a more fragrant loaf. It is good toasted or not.

text:
I was afraid this wasn't going to rise because the directions require that you add the yeast to the water and not to the dry ingredients as is usually recommended. Instead it rose too much; puffing out to fill the top of the breadmaker, and as a result, not browning on top. I finished it in the oven under the broiler for a minute or two. I had to cut off the "muffin top" to be able to slice the rest of the loaf for sandwiches. Taste and texture very good for sandwiches. Might need to tweak this a little to get it to bake more uniformly.

I have made this bread several times by the exact recipe and we LOVE it!  There have been times when I didn't have bread flour and just substituted all-purpose flour. I gave up and began searching this website.  Hoping I had the right one, I decided that from now on I will store the recipe inside the bread machine so I wouldn't lose it again. When I got ready to make the bread this morning, I opened my bread machine, and found my printed copy.  I guess I had the same great idea last time, haha.

Something goes wrong and the bread is very doughy and somehow the yeast is affected as it will not rise as well as the original recipe. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has given me trust issues. Why? Because CLEARLY the bread machine people don't want us to have perfect bread with all their crazy rules and no water-touching-yeast business. I've been using my bread machine for ages now and I've actually had loaves FAIL. How hard can bread machine bread be!? But this..wow. The crust ALONE is worth making it. I did modify but purely by necessity; I ran out of yeast and used 2 tsp instead of 2.25 tsp (absolutely no difference from what I can see/taste and I did a 2 lb loaf) and I used part unbleached white flour and part whole wheat (more unbleached than WW). I also only let the yeast proof for 7 minutes because I was excited/in a rush to get the bread going. Again, huge delicious loaf that I now have to try and save some for the rest of the family!

Soft in middle and crew crust, better than what you get at the market.  I took out of bread machine for the 3rd rise and baked in oven at 350 for 30 minutes as I wanted regular bread  shape and I don't like the paddle stuck in bread.

text:
I tried this recipe as is the first time around because i am a firm believer in trying the recipe before making any modifications. It was really good but too dense for my taste. My second time around here is what i modified; i subbed the sugar for honey, the oil for clarified butter and increased the salt to 1 1/2 tsp. it was amazing! Great taste, not too dense or too airy. I am only giving this 4 stars because of the modifications. The taste was excellent both times.

text:
I've used this recipe many times and it always turns out good.  However, the last couple of times I made it I used semolina flour to make semolina bread.  I didn't make any changes to the recipe, other than using semolina flour instead of all purpose flour, and it turned out perfect!  The first time I did it, I thought it might be a fluke, but after today, I know this is the perfect recipe for semolina bread too!  I set my machine on the basic setting with a medium crust for a 1.5 lb. loaf.  I don't know why one reviewer said to not use Canola oil.  I use it all the time without any problem.  I use a Cooks bread machine, and I get semolina flour at an Amish market in Columbus, New Jersey. Thanks for a great, easy recipe that ALWAYS yields a perfect loaf.  I'm going to try rye flour next!

text:
British bread!!  Ok, if you are like me and you are on the search for moist, chewy English style bread then look no further.  Your search has ended.  Some slight modifications are required to make it taste exactly like warburtons loaf.  Double the water (to 2 cups) and add 4 teaspoons of gluten.  Add a bit more oil (I use grape seed) and a bit more salt.  Thank god, no more dry, fluffy garbage from the supermarket.  Quality bread.  Outstanding!

Awesome recipe! I have modified this to add the extra salt and use 2 tbs agave instead if sugar. It makes a great loaf that is soft and stYs that way. I gave to stop my breadmaker about 10 mins early to prevent overbrownong even on the light cycle. This isn't the recipe, it is just my particular machine. Just added that if anyone has the same problem to let them know it's ok to stop the machines baking time early.

text:
This is the best white bread ever! The first time I made this, I followed the instructions even though it went against the order my machine says to put them in and was impressed with how big the bread got.  The second time, we decided to follow the order stated in my owners manuel (liquid, dry ingredients, yeast last in a well)and the bread got too tall for the machine.  It was actually pressed against the glass window.  lol  We will be making this recipe a lot.  We didn't make any changes to the ingredient list or the measurements.  This is perfect as is! Thank you for posting such an amazing recipe and to those who have posted reviews about this (which is why I chose to try it in the first place).

text:
I absolutely loved this recipe. I ended up making two loaves yesterday because my first loaf was gone within minutes. I'm not even kidding. I did add some Italian seasoning, parsley, and garlic powder because I love seasoned bread. I didn't measure it out, but I did end up having to add about 1/2cup more water because the dough was very dry. It was definitely because of the added seasonings, because I followed the recipe as written for the second loaf. I also read through other reviews and many said to add 2 tsp of salt instead of 1 tsp to keep it from falling. Worked like a charm. I will definitely be making this one (multiple times a day!) again.

I just tried this recipe, and it does seem to be pretty foolproof, I even changed a couple of things, I used half self rising flour(a def no no according to my bread maker instructions) and half all purpose flour for the flour part, and active yeast for the yeast part..when fully cooked it was about a half inch from the top of the pan, and might have been a little denser than some would like, but I actually like the uniform texture, it slices easily, and makes great sandwiches :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The absolute best bread! I increased the salt to 1 1/2 tsp, used 2 TBS of honey. I also used 1 1/2c organic whole wheat flour and 1 1/2c unbleached organic white flour instead of the bread flour. I waited until the yeast, water and honey were nice and foamy before I added the rest of the recipe. I did use canola oil. I baked 2 loaves, 1 in the bread machine and 1 in my loaf pan. I allowed the dough to rise for 45 min in the loaf pan before placing it a preheat 350 deg oven. It took about 18min. My 12 son saw it cooling and said "that is one ugly loaf of bread". He tasted it and said "unless dad doesn't like it, we will never again buy store bread". I am not a big bread eater but this is the bomb!!! Super super easy.

text:
It's the only recipe so far that seems to work correctly in my bread machine, but the downside, if you can call it that, is that it taste  like ordinary bread that I buy from the store. I may have to try some suggestions from other reviewers here about different ingredients.

All the other recipes I tried came out way too dense, but the bread itself was outstandingly delicious, almost like a pastry. Just munching on the crust was a real treat. But being so dense it was unsuitable for sandwiches. I may have to try them again using regular yeast and adding a little more salt like I did with this one.

text:
I found it short , too pale on top , too brown on bottom . I use 3Tbs oil, 1 and 1/2 tsp salt  , 3 Tbs w. sugar ,1 and 1/4cups of hot water , 2 TBS of dried milk powder, 3 cups flour (RH), make a well , put in 2tsp of Bread machine yeast cover , and program #4 ,cooking for 3 hours  -add all as listed , and its high , good crust ,ifI make Brown Bread I use 1/4 cup molasses to 1 cup hot water , add some Bran , it has always turned out well for me .  Bakealot

text:
The only good thing about this recipe, is that it is super easy!  It made a loaf of bread just fine (rose to very top of bread machine, but still ok), but the taste was not good at all.  It was bland and salty, and you could definitely tell that it had been made with oil and not butter! I am going to try this same concept recipe, but use butter instead of the oil, decrease both the yeast and salt amounts and maybe add an extra sprinkle of sugar.

text:
I've had my bread machine for over a year, using only the recipes that came with the machine.  Decided to give this one a try.  ABSOLUTELY the BEST loaves out of my bread machine.  I have made numerous times..using a couple alterations after reading other reviews.....more sugar 3 T (have also used honey) and a bit more salt (1 1/2 t) and I use 2 C bread flour, 1 C whole wheat.  I use the basic setting on the bread machine, light crust setting  This is my Go To recipe for every day bread...I make one or two loaves a week for my hubby & I.  You won't be disappointed.

text:
Like a lot of other reviewers I, too, was very hesitant about leaving the yeast in the water & sugar for 10 minutes but I did as instructed and I have to say, this is the BEST recipe for basic white bread I've ever used!! Better even than the recipe that came with my machine. I'm making my 3rd loaf in 4 days as I write this review. My family LOVES this bread! I am taking the advice of a reviewer and added an extra 1/2 tsp of salt as I've had problems with the loaf falling so we'll see how that goes, but overall I would recommend this recipe to anyone who wants a great tasting loaf of basic white bread. Thank you for sharing!!

Eilish

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1970496.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the MOST VERSATILE bread recipe I've encountered! I make this loaf in the BREAD MAKER but bake it in the oven. I add wet ingredients then dry then yeast on top and this recipe has never failed me! Differences in the recipe from above are a slight increase in yeast, added 0.33c RAW pumpkin seeds, 0.25c RAW sunflower seeds and 2 tbsp sesame seeds to the mixture.  For the flour I use the Multigrain Bread Flour Mix from Robin Hood (2 cups), and 1 cup of organic whole wheat flour, and increased the water to 1.25c.  Lastly, I mixed the dough  only on the dough cycle, remove the dough at the end of the cycle, and baked at 350 for 60min.  One more thing, before putting the dough in the oven to bake, I pressed the top of the loaf into parchment with sesame seeds and rolled oats on it, flipped it over and set it in the pan to bake.  Enjoy!

really love this recipe. I turn my machine off after the second kneading, and let it rest until it gets to where I feel it's 'high' enough...then I put it on 'bake' for 50 minutes...it's perfect, you can slice thinner slices!! Very basic and tasty!!! THANK YOU!

This turned out perfect!  Couldn't believe how easy this was!  I used this as a base and put 1 cup raisins, 2extra tablespoons of sugar, and 2 teaspoons of cinnamon for a wonderful cinnamon raisin bread! mofti

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So i just kinda riffed off this.  used hot tap water.  doubled the salt.  Used olive oil.  added the sugar.  added 2 teaspoons of yeast with the second slightly rounded.  added tablespoon and a half of dried rosemary.  generous pinch of thyme.  3 cups all purpose flour.  and then drizzled wild blossom honey stitching over top.  set my machine for white bread, 1.5 loaf, light crust.  let it run 5 minutes, restart it.  i open the machine for about 2 minutes while it was rising.  then right before its done cooking i gave it a butter glaze.   i must say, this is some of the most delicious bread i've ever had.  its like eating a chicken roast or enjoying some savory cake.  my loaf rose very well and i have the desired 'love handles' up top as well as a perfect juicy, fluffy, chewy center and a crispy buttery crust.  this bread also slices perfect for toast and sandwiches!  so apparently this is a solid enough recipe to mess around and still come out on top!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to bread machine recipe, one which I have used for years.  I often substitute other flours for 1-2 cups bread (I use unbleached white) flour, which have included spelt, amaranth, barley, whole wheat, or a bit (a 1/2 cup or less) of almond flour.  When using substitutes other than the almond flour I'll also add an extra tablespoon of water, and I've recently been adding a teaspoon or two of malted barley flour for enhanced heft and height (though it's just fine without as well).  I have also at times added about 1/2 cup of whole grain teff in addition to the 3 cups flour for a nice grainy texture.  Great basic recipe!

text:
Have made this bread four weeks in a row, once a week in my Zojirushi Bread Machine on the Medium Crust Setting.  Perfect every time!  I followed the advice of others and increased the salt by a 1/4 of a tsp.  I used straight Canola Oil and it worked fine - don;t know why others have had trouble...old oil maybe?  I also started subbing in Agave in lieu of White Sugar...totally worked fine as well.  
Finally a bread that I can make with Organic Bread Flour and other Organic Ingredients that I don't have to worry about - no more failed bread and ruined expensive ingredients!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great bread machine recipe. The 2nd time I made it, it was flat and dry. Why, because I used RAPID RISE YEAST. the 2nd time I used ACTIVE YEAST, RECIPE WITHOUT REALIZING IT. SO CHECK TO SEE YOU HAVE ACTIVE YEAST. YOU WILL HAVE TOO PUT 1 CUP 110 DEGREES, ADD YEAST, ADD SUGAR, AND LEAVE ALONE FOR 10 MIN. Just thought I would pass this along to people, like me, who use a bread machine. Happy Baking!

text:
I wanted a dairy free recipe due to lactose intolerance.  This recipe is perfect! I used 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour in place of white flour.  I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  I added a pinch extra of sugar, salt, and yeast to compensate for the heaviness of the wheat flour.  The bread came out fluffy inside with a flaky crust using the 1.5 lb/med crust setting on the bread machine.  I'm saving this recipe to make again!  Next time I'll try using more wheat flour and honey instead of white sugar.

userID:
9352938
Display Name:
cdminot
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I recently got my bread machine out of the moth balls (yikes!), and have been using recipes that came out of the owner's manual, a box mixes are just too expensive now. Well, needless to say, I've been less than thrilled with the recipes. They dry out so fast that the remaining loaf could soak up the entire Arkansas River!
I tried this just as the recipes stated for the first loaf, and I am sold! I have never, ever had a loaf of bread come out as well as store quality (the premium bread), but this did!
I made my second loaf, tweaked with some other reviewer's helpful hints, and tried cutting back on the yeast a bit, as the first loaf doubled as it was cooking! Monster loaf of bread! lol
The second also rose up more in the oven, but I divided the dough and made a little mini-loaf, and I will divide further next time, as it's still a little to big. I cannot wait to taste this one, as I cut back flour to 21/2 cups and added the 1/2 cup of wheat flour.
I have also never made bread that called for letting the yeast set in water for 10 minutes to foam up - but I wish I had known this trick years ago, as it would also let you know if you killed your yeast without wasting all the other ingredients as well! All I can say is, you learn something new everyday.
I made the first loaf 3 days ago, and at the very end of it, it was just starting to turn dry, so I am going to share this recipe with my daughter. Plus, no eggs/milk, cheaper to make!
No way to go wrong, so it's a win win!

This is the ONLY bread machine recipe I've made thus far (7 attempts)  that has WORKED.  THANK YOU!!!!!   Ignore your machine's instructions which tell you (at least mine does) to add liquids then dry ingredients.  That does not work.  Add the yeast to the water/sugar mixture first and you will have a beautiful loaf.

userID:

Display Name:
Tiffa
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is exceptional and now my absolute go-to.  I started by making it as described, and enjoyed the chewy loaf that made perfect sandwich bread with a really lovely crispy crust.   From there, I've used the basic outline of it, and had great success with modifications...

The same loaf made with 100% whole wheat bread flour turned out great.  Another time when I only had all-purpose white flour (not bread flour) I used that with the addition of a little bit of lemon juice, and it rose up beautifully and was soft and chewy.   I've added heaps of seeds and raisins and dates and nuts, with no problem rising.  I have a machine whose pan is a little squatter and wider than many, which I believe makes a better loaf.  That said, I am a complete convert to foaming the yeast first (like you do when you make bread by hand) rather than keeping the ingredients separate like typical instructions tell you for bread machines.  I haven't used another bread machine recipe since finding this one!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

userID:

Display Name:
Kathe

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe.  Tweaked it just a little.  1-1/2 cups each of King Arthur whole wheat white flour and white flour.  Added an extra 1/2 tsp of salt.  Use my bread machine to prepare the dough.  After the end of the cycle, put the dough into a greased loaf pan, cover it and leave it to rise for about 30 mins.  Preheat oven to 350 degrees.  Bake for 25 mins until the top is nicely browned.  I can't keep it in the house.  My husband cuts into it before it's even partially cooled and will polish off 1/2 loaf in an hour.  This is such an easy recipe, I have no problem baking several batches a week.  So much better than store-bought.

text:
Wow. I made my first bread using this recipe - Hecker's All Purpose flour. Instead of using sugar, I used honey and instead of v. oil, I used melted butter.  The result is a bread that taste naturally sweet with a tinge of buttery!  Also my butter was salted so 1 tsp of salt is enough - i added 1.25 tsp because i read that it will hold up better but the bread did taste a tad of salt.  Held up so perfectly (no collapsing) and while light and fluffy, it was so sturdy and great for sandwiches. In fact, it was so good I have been noshing on it on its own. KEEPER!

text:
Awesome!  Got rave reviews from my guests - good flavor, texture and appearance.  I brushed alittle butter on after it came out of the machine and sliced it after it cooled.  It sliced easily.  I didn't intentionally substitute, but i used olive oil instead of a standard vegetable oil. Delicious!  Great starter bread machine recipe.

A tip for anybody baking bread, get good quality bread flour and measure it by weight as it tends to settle. I use King Arthur bread flour and measure 4.25 oz per cup - this recipe has turned out perfect everytime.

text:
I followed the directions exactly and ran into a few problems.
1. Loaf collapsed. I do see that others recommend adding more salt to remedy this, however.
2. The loaf stuck to the sides of my bread machine tin and I'm not sure why. I've never had a loaf stick before so this baffled me. I had to pretty much hack at it to get it out.

The chunks of it I ate were pretty good, however. I am wondering if the problems are because my bread machine is a bit larger than others?
I will try it again but add the extra salt and see what happens! :)

All in all it is a very quick, easy, and good bread to make!

text:
I made this bread yesterday according to the recipe and it really did seem logical to me to add the yeast to the water.  Toward the end of the cycle, I watched the dough rise nicely.  Then after 15 minutes I checked it again, and the dough collapsed just before the bake cycle.  But I thought well there’s nothing more I could do about it and I just let the machine run its course.  I took the bread out of the pan turned it upside down on a rack.  I was surprised to see the crust was beautifully browned and when I cut into it, it had a wonderful texture.  Well needless to say we had the bread for supper.  It was excellent!  The next time I will add a little more salt like so many reviewers suggested.  Thanks for a great recipe!

I made this while sleeping last night!  woke up to the great smell of fresh baked bread throughout my whole home!  Yum!

I was scared, like some other reviewers reported to be as well, in adding yeast to water.  My machine states to add it to the flour mixture last, not touching water.  But i liked the comment that was posted " what did I have to lose" so I tried it....without fail!!!

My bread for the first time in a LONG TIME turned out so perfect.  it rose so big.  the only change i made 9 not bc I wanted to but bc that is all I had in the house) was i added EVO instead of veg oil.  I also used 1 1/2 white and 1 1/2 whole wheat flour.

this is a KEEPER!!! Thanks for sharing

However, don't try this with whole wheat flour or else it will come out kind of dense.. maybe reduce the amount of flour, but then again, I'm no cook!

text:
its fluffy enough except...
- taste is not great. the yeast smell is overpowering from prep to bake time. 
- you cant use express settings (it says 3hours to make so i did the regular 3 hours)
- the top collapsed, but did not affect the inside fluffiness. the underside had moisture when i removed from pan, and at first slice, parts were slightly damp. the sides are still burnt despite Light setting.

overall, its okay, but not the best I've done. id watch out for the tweaks that other people have done.

None
country:
None
text:
This bread was soooo delicious. I was a little apprehensive b/c this was my first bread making experience, I didn't have all the right ingredients, and because a few ppl said the bread was horrible. But I took a chance and I am glad I did. Firstly I didn't have bread machine yeast so I substituted w reg dry active yeast. Secondly I didn't have bread flour so I used 2 cups off all purpose and then threw in a cup of self rising for good measure. Third, although I did have vegetable oil I always substitute butter for oil. Well the bread was so awesome. It was so light and fluffy. I will definitely make it again and I will try different variations for different flavors. I will also make it as the recipe calls I just didn't happen to have all of those ingredients. A+

text:
WOW!  Finally a bread recipe that works, haha!  After receivingmy new Kenmore bread maker for Christmas, I tried out the recipe provided in the manual- the bread turned out to be a HUGE mass of weird, crumbly mess.  This recipe's ratios sounded better, the dough looked better (tacky to the touch).  Don't be afraid to let the yeast proof w/ the water/sugar b4 adding dry ingredients.  I used evoo instead of veg oil and 2 tsp salt both added great flavor.  I will save this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is amazing. I just purchased a bread machine for christmas (West Bend), and the recipes in the booklet that came with it are just so-so. When I read all the reviews, I thought I'd give this a try. The only change I made is that I used butter instead of oil. The crust came out beautifully crispy, the interior was light and fluffy, and a very nice, mild flavor to it. I was really amazed at how much the bread rose - it was bigger and fluffier than all the other breads I made so far, and it used less flour!  I guess I found my white bread recipe, now it's on to the next quest: finding the perfect whole wheat bread recipe for my bread machine.

country:
None
text:
Turned out great!  First time using this bread machine, or any for that matter, and I'm not a baker...  I followed the instructions explicitly, and chose to use unbleached white flour, organic sugar, kosher salt, canola oil, and regular fast acting yeast, all from my local Henry's here in So Cal...  The top sank a little, but I'm not sure what it's supposed to look like, so I think it was okay.  The crust was light brown and lightly crunchy, and the bread had a nice consistency.  It made awesome toast this morning!  Next time I may experiment with the ingredients just as others here do, but the basic recipe is so good and simple, you can't go wrong!  BTW, I used a DAK Turbo V baker my neighbor gave me years ago, and it did an incredible job... Total time was 3.5 hours on normal, not turbo...

text:
The first time I made this, I used the "fast bake" setting on my machine, bcz the manual said to use that setting if I use rapid rise yeast (bread machine yeast). The first time it came out very heavy. I followed the directions this time &used the normal rise and bake setting, except for using olive oil and an extra 1/2 tsp salt. It came out beautiful! So light and fluffy..great with butter and honey. A little too fluffy/crumbly for sandwiches, but regardless, this bread is so tasty for it being such a simple recipe-and the aroma while baking made everyone hungry! It was gone in a day.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy and foolproof indeed!  Comes out perfect every time.  The only time i messed it up was when i forgot the salt until it was too late to add it.  The bread still turned out good, even though i could taste the difference without the salt.  The lack of salt also affected the rising of the dough.  It didn't rise the same.

I have used this recipe many times, often following the exact recipe, and other times with the following variations:

2-1/2 c. white flour + 1/2 c. whole wheat flour

2 c. white flour + 1 c. whole wheat flour

olive oil instead of vegetable oil

sea salt instead of regular salt

the past few times, i've made it with some less refined, tan-colored, granulated sugar (can't remember what it was called)

i have also used Sucanat (a brand of whole cane sugar)

Great, easy recipe!  I love this bread!!

I'm giving this the highest rating because it's the best loaf of bread that I've made so far.  I've only had my machine for a couple of weeks, and this is only my fourth loaf. I think that it only rose about 20% from the raw ingredients.  Is this how it is supposed to be?

text:
This bread is soooo great.   Some reviews mentioned the loaf falling in the middle. We followed the directions to a T and it came out perfect. The dough seems very wet in comparison to other breads we've made and I was half tempted to add some flour... but nothing erks me more than when people change the recipe and then give bad remarks... so I stuck to it and boy was I glad I did.  Well worth the little leg work at the beginning. This is the only bread machine recipe I've used where you buck the system and create a yeast starter rather than following the manufacturers ingredient order. It is incredibly soft and tasty. This will be our staple bread we make and then we'll just have fun on the side.  We live overseas and finding soft bread is always so hard. We actually buy 4-5 loaves at Fuddruckers up in the capital city whenever we travel there (4 hours away) and bring it back home. Thanks Diggetydog for providing my family with soft bread again!

userID:
4611596
Display Name:
Teresa
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, like the others trying this recipe, I was shocked at putting the instant breadmachine yeast, luke warm water and sugar together in the bread pan. But there were so many great comments that I couldn't resist to try it.  I have made this recipe 3 times in the past 3 days. Each time the bread rose a little more than the time before. Each time I used different breadmachine setting, decreased the sugar amount and allowed the yeast to rise longer than 10mins in bread pan. Today, I think that I have perfected it.  I have a 2 lbs Regal KitchenPro Bread machine which is over 15 yrs old(still in great working condition).  Before adding 2 1/2 tsps yeast, I warmed the outside of the bad pan by running hot water over it, meanwhile in a measuring cup I put 1 1/4 cp lukewarm water added 1 1/2 tblsp of sugar until dissolved, then in the warmed bread pan added the bread machine yeast then poured the measuring cup with lukewarm sugar water over it. Once the yeast rose (became bubbly in the pan) I added 1/4cp olive oil, 3cps flour,1 1/2tspn salt, dried herbs 1 tsp & 1-2 tsps flaxseeds.e dough doesn't form a ball & still dry add warm water a tblspn at a time until it forms a ball. I just took baked bread out of the machine and it rose to the top of the 2 lbs pan! ammazing!  I hope this helps others!

text:
This makes a nice loaf of bread. I don't buy bread at the store anymore. I use this recipe and make at least 4 loaves of this bread each week. I do as a previous poster recommended and add 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt instead of the 1 teaspoon in the recipe. I use the dough cycle of the bread machine which takes it through the first rise. I knead the dough and let it rise a second time, then brush with egg whites and bake at 375 degree F for 30 minutes. It's perfect every time.

The absolute best white bread recipe for a bread machine I've found during the 6 years I've owned a bread machine.  Perfect crust, texture and flavor. Great basic recipe!  Thank you!

text:
I needed a recipe for bread that didn't call for milk (I was out). I followed LUBSY's variation, as I wanted a larger loaf with a mix of whole wheat and white flours. It turned out very nice, except that as my loaf cooled the sides sucked in a little. I think my loaf may have been a little too moist... because I prefer to prepare the dough by hand, and use the bread machine only for baking, I'm not sure if my bake time was too short or if I just needed to add a little more flour. When I let my machine do all the work, loaves tend to be misshapen and I have to pull the paddles out of the loaf. Otherwise, the loaf had a great texture and flavor and I was very pleased.

text:
Excellent and oh so easy!  Can use with the bread machine's dough cycle and use as dough for whatever you please.  I have used it as dough for cooking a loaf in the oven, which makes a more "traditional" shaped loaf, and have also used it as a base dough for making pizza, cinnamon buns, dinner rolls, etc.  You can use the "dough" cycle on your bread machine and the results are great.  First time I used this recipe it tasted a little yeasty, but I had 3 year's expired yeast and had upped the yeast to compansate.  After buying fresh yeast, followed the recipe exactly and have had great results ever since.  Thanks!

text:
Lovely bread, my 4th loaf EVER, and the only one that came out of my new bread machine fluffy. (Never baked any bread before the bread machine) I did as the recipe said, starting the yeast with the water and sugar 1st. I adjusted as many reviewers said, using 1.5 tsp of salt, and I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. I also used 2.75 c. all-purpose flour because that's what I have. (I'll get bread flour next trip to a food retailer) and added some herbs (Italian seasoning, fresh rosemary) for a less bland loaf. Due to my previous "experiments", I was on my way to pre-activating the yeast, so this recipe fell right in with what I was thinking anyways. I will from now on ALWAYS pre-activate the yeast for yeast breads. Yay!

text:
This bread recipe made a very tasty finished product but, the texture just doesn't work for me. I tried the recipe, as it is written, the first time. It rose and then promptly fell. When it finished baking, it had more of a dry, crumbly, falling apart cake-like texture rather than a bread. Then I tried some of the alterations provided by other reviewers and still got a totally unsatisfactory loaf of bread. It falls apart if I try to make anything with the finished product other than toast. I'm sure, especially after reading other reviews, that this is an excellent bread recipe for some bread machines but, not for mine. Thanks for submitting the recipe so that I could try it out.  :)

text:
I have only made two loaves of bread EVER, since I just got my bread machine 2 days ago (hence the 4 stars - I only really have store bought to compare to! ;)). However, the first loaf I made from the recipes provided through the manufacturer was dense and the crust was HARD as a rock!  Soooo... I turned to my favorite recipe site and found this one - and it is moist, fluffy and gorgeous - and it rose more than the other loaf I made with the manufacturers' directions!!  FORGET THE RULES! ;) Obviously, they are meant to be broken if the result is this bread!!  (Will check back and provide a more thorough and insightful review when I have experimented a bit more. GREAT bread!! :D)
August 23, 2010 - Edited to add: This is still my go-to recipe for bread, 1.5 years later! I have made several different types of loaves since by adding other ingredients: Shredded cheddar cheese, onion, egg, milk, even cinnamon and raisins! This loaf comes out great every.single.time! :D A+++++++++++++++!!!!!!

text:
The best recipe I've used so far!  I was starting to think maybe my bread machine was the problem, as most other recipes I've tried have risen to much or ended up being dry and grainy.  This was perfect.

I'm not a fan of white flour so I used 2 cups multigrain flour and 1 cup white and it turned out perfectly.  Also dropped the yeast to 2 tsp to accomodate for a higher altitude.

I think next time I will try honey instead of sugar and maybe add some milk powder.  This recipe is a keeper though.

text:
Thanks so much for this recipe! My husband never likes the bread from our bread machine...but this was a HUGE hit with him. He's requesting it for his sanwiches!

I made the original recipe as written and it turned out perfectly every time. Some tweeks that I've incorporated over time include using 2-1/2 c flour and 1/2 c potato flakes. I have also used milk or buttermilk in place of the water. Those changes have given me a loaf that stays fresh for nearly a week!!

Try slitting the top and brushing with butter....

Thanks again for a fabulous recipe!

text:
New to using a bread machine and this is the best recipe I have tried so far. I did mess it up a few times before I got it right because I used bread machine yeast and it uses a lot less of that type of yeast then called for. I learned by looking on the Red Star Yeast website that you only use 1/2 tsp yeast per cup of flour. That coupled with living at 4500 feet elevation here in Salt Lake City, well, you can imagine how much that first loaf rose...

Carla

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/441657.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I received a handy-me-down bread machine and wanted to try it out to see how it worked. The recipes in the manual were old and used powdered milk and shortening (Yuck) so I looked up this one. The 1st batch I used 1.5 tsp salt and 2 tsp instant yeast and it was good, but just a tad too salty. The 2nd batch I used 2.25 tsp yeast and melted butter for the oil and only 1 tsp salt and it was great! I didn't have any problem either time with the rise, but the second was higher which I liked a little better. The one with butter tasted a little different but I liked both equally. Oh, and I let the water/yeast foam 10 min. like directed the first time, but the second poured it in the machine, layered the oil, flour, with salt on top and pushed start. My machine had a 15 min. wait before mixing automatically so that worked out just fine! (Black & Decker B1600) As a freebee its doing great with THIS recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this bread it fell and had a "yeasty" taste to it.  I had to throw the loaf away.  But after adjusting some of the measurements, I had success and a very good loaf of bread machine bread.  This is what I did:
only 2 tsp. of yeast instead of 2 1/2
added 1 T. of sugar for a total of 3 T. instead of 2 T.
changed the 1/4 c. of oil to butter
added 1/2 tsp. of salt for a total of 1 1/2 tsp.
I didn't find this bread to be too sweet, like some other reviews.  The texture was light and slightly on the chewy side.  Overall, above average.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Ok, here's what I did....divided flour evenly between white whole wheat and bread flour.  Added the extra 1/2 tsp of salt, subbed brown sugar for the white and added in 2 tbsp of milled flax seed.  I've only tested the  bottom end of the bread and I did bake it on "medium- basic".  It did fall somewhat even with the extra salt. Next time I will make it on the "medium-light" setting.

userID:
2320636
Display Name:
JR
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

25
favoritesCount:
182

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/37867.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
New Review:  Try adjusting the setting on the bread machine.  I needed to take my bread machine in to my son's class for a pot luck and the teacher wanted a basic white bread.  I thought I would give this recipe another try.  I added the additional 1/2 tsp. salt as suggested and the loaf did not fall and looked beautiful, but it tasted a bit salty-I usually cook with sea salt or kosher - so I do not know if that made the saltier flavor, but I have other bread recipes that use as much as a tablespoon of salt to tablespoon of sugar ratio.  I tried the original recipe again, but adjusted my setting on the bread machine to small/regular loaf instead of large white and the loaf looked perfect.  I have made it again using butter instead of oil and if you like a softer, finer crumb use the butter.  If you like a firmer, open crumb use oil.  For a basic white bread, I prefer the butter and would give it 5 stars.  I would give the oil recipe 4 stars and the leftovers made wonderful bread cubes for stuffing.  

Original review (3 stars)I will have to try this again.  Mine turned out a little dense and fell.  Read review that suggested more salt and will see if that helps.  I also thought the flavor was a little more bland than most white bread recipes.  Since I usually make bread from scratch and don't use the machine as much...I will blame the results on operator error.

text:
This is wonderful bread. My husband won't eat plain white bread and he LOVES this one. It has a great texture and the crust is not as overwhelming as alot of bread machine crusts. This is so simple. Thanks for the great recipe!

**Update: Tried this with half home-ground whole wheat flour and half bread flour, 1 1/2 tsp of salt, 1 1/2 Tbs. vital wheat gluten, and 1 Tbs. of dough enhancer. Turned out beautifully! It was a spongier texture this way and held up well for sandwiches.**

text:
A delicious white bread!  I have made it about 4 times and it always comes out nicely.  I substituted about 1/2 wheat flour as another reviewer suggested and it turned out well too...I prefer using honey in wheat breads though, so I will try that instead of sugar next time.  The dough was a little dry at first so I have been adding an extra tablespoon or two of water if necessary.  I use the dough setting on my machine and finished it off in a 350 oven for 30 mins. after letting it rise for an extra half hour...perfect every time!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this recipe twice to make sure I didn't goof it up since it got so many rave reviews, but it was disappointing each time. The bread was not fluffy as I had hoped, instead it was dense and...greasy!! The first time I made this bread, I was thinking 1/4 C of oil was a lot and I was right. The bread left an oily sheen on my hand as I cut it. I baked this last night again for the second time to make sure I followed the recipe to the T and it was the same thing! First loaf went into the trash, second loaf...well, I am making the husband eat it since he doesn't seem to mind the greasiness.

WOW.  Honestly, I didn't know my breadmaker could MAKE bread like this.  I don't have a "light crust" option on my machine, but the crust was still crispy without being hard.  The bread itself...well, it just came out and it's almost gone.  My two-year-old said, "Mmmmm, good bread, Mama!"  If that's not an endorsement, I don't know what is!

One note - my jar of yeast said to use 1/2 tsp per cup of flour.  Next time I'll use two teaspoons instead of 1.5 - but it's still exceptional!  No more mixes for me!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
***For those that worry about adding yeast to water first, contrary to the machine instructions, it is perfectly fine as long as you are not using the delay settings. Liquid activates the yeast.  If using delay, then yeast should go on top so it is not activated prematurely.  Just be sure  it does not sit in contact with the salt.

This is the best white bread recipe I have used with my breadmaker.  I had always made loaf bread by hand, so it took some getting used to. I prefer to make it to the dough stage in the breadmaker and then shape it and rise it by hand in a loaf pan.
